Such appeal must be made within thirty (30) working days from the date of the Forester(s) determination and only after all issues relevant to the permit process have been determined. Upon receipt of the appeal, the City Manager will have ten (10) working days to grant relief upon an adequate showing that undue hardship would be suffered if not granted. 
(b)  After having been denied relief by the City Manager as provided in (a) above, the owner shall have the right of appeal to City Council. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the City Clerk, within ten (10) working days after denial of relief by the City Manager, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal. After receipt of the written statement, the City Clerk shall schedule the appeal for hearing by the City Council on the next regular agenda. The Owner shall be notified of the time of the hearing at least seven (7) days prior to such hearing. Proper mailing to the address shown on the application shall be adequate notification. The decision and order of City Council on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 0-1819-34, § 14) 
Chapter 11 - RESERVED 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-0405-25, § 5, adopted Jan. 25, 2005, deleted Ch. 11 in its entirety. Former Ch. 11 pertained to housing requirements and derived from Ord. No. 0-7475-7; Ord. No. 0-9596-45; Ord. No. 0-9900-11; and Ord. No. 0-0001-24. 
Chapter 12 - LABOR RELATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Discrimination in employment, § 7-102 et seq., prohibition against strikes, § 15-707. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 12-101. - Policy. 
(a)  Each employee shall have the right, freely and without fear of penalty or reprisal, to form, join, and assist a labor organization or to refrain from any such activity, and each employee shall be protected in the exercise of this right. 
(b)  The right to assist a labor organization extends to participation in the management of the organization and acting for the organization in the capacity of an organization representative, including presentation of its views to management officials, elected officials of the City, or other appropriate authorities. This subsection does not authorize participation in the management of a labor organization or acting as a representative of such an organization by a supervisor, management official, confidential employee, or by any other employee when the participation or activity would result in a conflict or apparent conflict of interest or otherwise be inconsistent with law, this chapter, or with the official duties of the employee. 
(c)  The right of employees to assist a labor organization does not include the right to participate in a strike. Any employee who participates in a strike may be discharged by the City Manager immediately and without further cause. No one participating in a strike shall be allowed to acquire any benefits gained by collective bargaining. The status of participants in a strike shall never be a matter of collective bargaining. 
(d)  Membership in any labor organization shall be determined by each individual employee; provided, however, that in bargaining units where employees have selected a labor organization as exclusive representative, an agreement may be negotiated which provides that non-members of the labor organization shall pay to it a service charge for the negotiation and administration of a collective bargaining agreement in an amount not to exceed the regular periodic membership dues of the labor organization. 
(e)  The employer shall take the action required to assure that employees are apprised of their rights under this chapter, and that no interference, restraint, coercion, or discrimination is practiced to encourage or discourage membership in a labor organization or other exercise by employees of their rights under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-102. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases when used in this chapter, shall for the purposes of this chapter, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this article, except where the context otherwise requires. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-103. - Employer. 
    Employer is the City Manager or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-104. - Employee. 
    "Employee" is a full-time employee of the City, but does not include, for the purposes of exclusive recognition, a management official, a supervisor, a confidential employee, an employee engaged in the administration of this chapter, and a temporary or seasonal employee hired for a time certain of less than six (6) months during a fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-105. - Confidential employee. 
    Confidential employees are all employees of the City Attorney's Office, all employees of the Personnel Office, and one secretarial or clerical employee designated by each Department Head and the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-106. - Supervisor. 
    Supervisor is an employee having the authority, in the interest of the employer, to do one of the following: to hire, transfer, suspend, lay off, recall, promote, discharge, assign, reward, or discipline other employees, or responsibly to direct them, or to adjust their grievances, if in connection with the foregoing the exercise of authority is not of a mere routine or clerical nature, but requires the use of independent judgment. Examples of nonsupervisory positions from the Fiscal Year 1975 Authorized Positions Chart include the following: Fire Captain, Police Sergeant, Maintenance Foreman, Sanitation Foreman, Community Center Supervisor I, Code Compliance Inspector II, Programmer II, Planner I, Building Inspector II, Construction Inspector II, and Engineering Technician II. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-107. - Management official. 
    Management official is an employee having authority to make, or to influence effectively the making of, a policy necessary to the employer with respect to personnel, procedures, or programs. An employee influences effectively policy decision when his or her role extends beyond that of an expert or professional rendering resource information or recommendations with respect to the policy in question to the point of active participation in the ultimate determination as to what the policy in fact will be. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-108. - Labor organization. 
    Labor organization is a lawful organization of any kind in which employees participate and which exists for the purpose, in whole or in part, of dealing with employers concerning compensation, hours, grievances, and other terms and conditions of employment, but does not include an organization which: 
(1)  Assists or participates in a strike against the City or imposes a duty or obligation to conduct, assist, or participate in such a strike; 
(2)  Advocates the overthrow of the constitutional form of government of the United States, or any political subdivision thereof; 
(3)  Discriminates with regard to the terms or conditions of membership because of race, color, creed, sex, age, or national origin; or 
(4)  Is not in conformance with section 12-208 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-109. - Strike. 
    Strike is any work stoppage or slowdown or other behavior by an employee who, individually or by concerted action with others and without the approval his superior, willfully absents himself from his position or abstains in whole or in part from the full, faithful, and proper performance of his duties for the purpose of inducing, influencing or coercing a change in conditions or compensation, or the rights, privileges, or obligations of employment. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-110. - Day. 
    Day is a calendar day, except that when a limited time period specified in this chapter ends on a Saturday, Sunday, or recognized City holiday, the limited time period shall be extended to the next work day of the employer's administrative offices. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-111. - Direct economic issues. 
    Direct economic issues are salaries, wages, rates of pay, or any other issues subject to collective bargaining which require the appropriation of monies by the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 12-201. - Administration: Hearing Examiners. 
(a)  The City Council shall appoint a Chief Hearing Examiner and at least two (2) Associate Hearing Examiners. All persons so appointed shall be members of the Labor Panels of the American Arbitration Association, the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, or the National Mediation Board. The Chief Hearing Examiner, in case of his inability to serve, shall assign one of the Associate Hearing Examiners to hear and decide cases as they arise. The Hearing Examiner hearing a case shall be reimbursed for his services at a rate not to exceed twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per hour for time served in hearing and deciding the case. The Chief Hearing Examiner shall prescribe regulations needed to administer the functions of Hearing Examiners under this chapter. All hearings shall be recorded on tape to provide a permanent record. 
(b)  The Hearing Examiner shall: 
(1)  Decide issues related to the appropriate unit submitted for his consideration; 
(2)  Decide questions pertaining to objections to elections and issues of challenged ballots as provided in section 12-202(f) of this Code; 
(3)  Decide unfair labor practice complaints which representatives of the parties have failed to resolve informally in meetings held during the fifteen (15) day period after the complaining party has notified the other party of its alleged unfair labor practice; 
(4)  Decide alleged violations of the standards of conduct of labor organizations; and 
(5)  Decide questions as to whether a grievance is subject to a negotiated grievance procedure as provided in section 12-206 of this Code. 
(c)  The Hearing Examiner shall have the authority to: 
(1)  Grant requests for appearance of witnesses or production of documents; 
(2)  Rule upon offers of proof and receive relevant evidence; 
(3)  Take or cause a deposition to be taken whenever the ends of justice would be served thereby; 
(4)  Limit lines of questioning or testimony which are immaterial, irrelevant, or unduly repetitious; 
(5)  Regulate the course of the hearing and, if appropriate, exclude from the hearing persons who engage in misconduct and strike all related testimony of witnesses refusing to answer any questions ruled to be proper; 
(6)  Hold conferences for the settlement or simplification of the issues by consent of the parties or upon his own motion; 
(7)  Dispose of procedural requests, motions, or similar matters, which shall be made part of the record of the proceeding; 
(8)  Examine and cross-examine witnesses and to introduce into the record documentary or other evidence; 
(9)  Request the parties at any time during the hearing to state their respective positions concerning any issue in the case or theory in support thereof; 
(10)  Continue the hearing from day-to-day, or adjourn it to a later day, by announcement thereof at the hearing or by appropriate notice; and 
(11)  Prepare, issue, and serve his decision to the parties. 
(d)  A complaint alleging a violation of section 12-207(b)(4) of this Code shall receive the highest priority treatment by the Chief Hearing Examiner. The Chief Hearing Examiner or an Associate Hearing Examiner assigned by him, shall commence the hearing of such a complaint within twenty-four (24) hours after the complaint has been made. The fifteen (15) day period for informally resolving unfair labor practice complaints shall be waived when the complaint alleges a violation of said section 12-207(b)(4). If the Hearing Examiner, based on the evidence presented, finds that there exists a reasonable cause to believe that a section 12-207(b)(4) violation is occurring, he shall issue an order which provides for cessation of the alleged violative conduct pending disposition of the complaint. 
(e)  Upon finding a violation of this chapter, the Hearing Examiner will make disposition of the matters before him. The Hearing Examiner may order the respondent to cease and desist from such violative conduct and may require the respondent to take such affirmative actions, including back pay to employees, as he deems appropriate to effectuate the policies of this chapter. The hearing examiner shall assess the costs of the hearing between the parties based on the merits of the case. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-202. - Exclusive recognition. 
(a)  A labor organization seeking exclusive recognition shall submit to the employer a roster of its officers and representatives, a copy of its Charter and Constitution and By-Laws, and a statement of its objectives and affirmation of its compliance with section 12-208 of this Code. 
(b)  The City Council shall accord exclusive recognition to a labor organization when the organization has been selected, in a secret ballot election, by a majority of the employees in an appropriate bargaining unit as their representative. When a labor organization has been accorded exclusive recognition, it is the exclusive representative of employees in the unit and is entitled to act for and to negotiate agreements covering all employees in the unit. It is responsible for representing the interests of all employees in the unit without discrimination and without regard to labor organization membership. 
(c)  Bargaining units shall ensure a clear and identifiable community of interest among the employees concerned, promote effective dealings between the labor organization and the employer, and promote the efficiency of City operations. Therefore, there shall be established only three (3) bargaining units as a result of secret ballot elections. One bargaining knit shall include all uniformed fire personnel; a second bargaining unit shall include all commissioned police officers; the third bargaining unit shall include all employees not otherwise excluded. No bargaining unit shall be established it if includes: 
(1)  Any management official or supervisor or confidential employee; 
(2)  An employee engaged in administering this chapter; or 
(3)  A temporary or seasonal employee hired for a time certain of less than six (6) months during a fiscal year. 
(d)  All elections shall be conducted by secret ballot. Each employee in the bargaining unit shall be eligible to vote and shall be provided the opportunity to choose the labor organization he or she wishes to represent him or her from among those on the ballot, or "no union." When no category on the ballot receives a majority of the valid ballots cast, a runoff election shall be held between the two (2) categories receiving the largest and second largest number of votes in the first election. Elections may be held to determine whether: 
(1)  A labor organization should be recognized as the exclusive representative of employees in the unit; 
(2)  A labor organization should replace another labor organization as the exclusive representative; or 
(3)  A labor organization should cease to be the exclusive representative. 
(e)  The employer shall call and hold an election upon receipt of a timely, written petition signed by no less than thirty (30) percent of the employees in an appropriate bargaining unit indicating their desire to be represented by a particular labor organization or to change or to withdraw recognition. No labor organization will be permitted to intervene in the election proceeding and secure a place on the ballot unless it has submitted a timely, written petition signed by no less than twenty (20) percent of the employees in the unit indicating their desire to be represented by that particular labor organization. The employer may hold an election when he has evidence supporting a good faith belief that the labor organization no longer is the choice of employees in the bargaining unit. 
(f)  When the employer has received an appropriate petition, the employer shall post notices to all employees containing information as to the name of the petitioner and a description of the bargaining unit involved. All interested labor organizations wishing to participate in the election must seek intervention within the ten (10) day period following the date of the posting of the notice by submitting a timely, written petition with the employer and otherwise meeting the requirements of this chapter. As soon as possible after the close of the period of intervention, the employer shall meet with representatives of the successful petitioner to arrange the details of the election. Following the meeting, the employer shall post appropriate notices of election. Such notices shall set forth details and procedures for the election, the appropriate unit, the eligibility period, the date, hour, and place of the election and shall contain a sample ballot which is clearly marked "sample" on its face. The employer shall provide the voting booths and ballot boxes. Each labor organization on the ballot and the employer may be represented by no more than two (2) observers of its own selection at the polling place. The observers' function is to see that the election is conducted fairly, the security of the ballot is maintained, and all eligible voters are given an opportunity to cast a ballot. At the conclusion of the balloting the ballots will be counted by the observers and an appropriate tally of ballots will be issued. Representatives of the labor organization and the employer shall sign the tally of ballots indicating that the tally is correct. The signing of the tally does not constitute a waiver of any rights by any party to file objections. If any party wishes to file objections or the number of challenged ballots are sufficient in number to affect the results of the election, such issue shall be submitted in accordance with the procedures set forth in section 12-201 of this Code within five (5) days of the conclusion of the balloting. The City Manager shall promptly report the final results of the election to the City Council. 
(g)  There shall be no election to determine whether a labor organization should become, or continue to be recognized as, exclusive representative of the employees in any unit within twelve (12) months after a prior valid election with respect to such unit. When an agreement covering a bargaining unit has been signed by the employer and the incumbent exclusive representative, an election petition will not be timely unless filed with the employer not earlier than October 1 and not later than October 15. 
(h)  Recognition of a labor organization does not: 
(1)  Preclude an employee, regardless of whether he is in a unit of exclusive recognition, from exercising rights established by law, or from choosing his own representative in the exercise of such rights; or 
(2)  Preclude the employer from consulting or dealing with lawful associations, not qualified as a labor organization, with respect to matters or policies which involve individual members of the association or are of particular applicability to it or its members. These consultations and dealings shall be so limited that they do not assume the character of consultation or dealings on matters of general employee-management policy covering employees in the bargaining unit or extend to areas where recognition of the interests of one employee group may result in discrimination against or injury to the interests of other employees. 
(i)  When a labor organization has been found to have committed a section 12-207(b)(4) unfair labor practice, the City Manager shall report promptly this finding to the City Council, and the City Manager may recommend that the labor organization's exclusive recognition be revoked, any existing agreements be voided, and that the labor organization not qualify as a labor organization under this chapter for a period of twelve (12) months. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-203. - Municipal powers and employer rights. 
(a)  Nothing herein contained shall be construed or interpreted so as to infringe upon or remove the prerogatives of the City to operate and manage affairs in all respects in accordance with its responsibilities and powers of authority, nor shall the right to collective bargaining extend to such matters. 
(b)  The employer retains the right, in accordance with this Code and the Charter of the City, 
(1)  To hire, direct, promote and take disciplinary action against employees; 
(2)  To relieve employees from duties because of lack of work or for other legitimate reasons; 
(3)  To maintain the efficiency of government operations entrusted to them; 
(4)  To determine the methods, means, and personnel by which such operations are to be conducted; and 
(5)  To take whatever actions may be necessary to carry out the mission of the City in situations of emergency. 
(c)  The requirements of this section shall be expressly stated in the initial or basic agreement and apply to all supplemental, implementing, subsidiary, or informal agreements between the employer and the labor organization. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-204. - Negotiation of agreements. 
(a)  The employer and a labor organization that has been accorded exclusive recognition, through appropriate representatives, shall bargain collectively with respect to wages, salaries, hours, rates of pay, grievances, working conditions, and other terms and conditions of employment, so far as may be appropriate under the Code and the Charter of the City. 
(b)  The employer and the labor organization, in fulfillment of their mutual obligation to bargain collectively, shall meet at reasonable times and confer in good faith with respect to wages, salaries, hours, rates of pay, grievances, working conditions, and other terms and conditions of employment, or the negotiation of an agreement, or any question arising thereunder, and the execution of a written agreement incorporating the results of such negotiations if requested by either party, but such obligation does not compel either party to agree to a proposal or require the making of a concession. 
(c)  A party desiring to initiate negotiations for a new agreement shall notify the other party on or before January 5. At this time of notification, the parties shall inform the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service of their intent to conduct negotiations for a new agreement. Negotiations shall begin on or before January 15 unless the parties mutually agree to another date. 
(d)  The employer shall enter into no agreement with a labor organization without the authorization of the city council. 
(e)  Agreements entered into by the employer which require the appropriation of monies are expressly made subject to the annual appropriation of said monies by the City Council. 
(f)  Once the parties enter into an agreement, neither party shall be required to engage in additional negotiations on any issues during the term of that agreement unless required by the provisions of the agreement or this chapter. 
(g)  The expiration date of all agreements shall be June 30 at midnight; provided, however, and subject to the annual appropriation of monies by the City Council, an agreement may be for a period of time greater than one fiscal year. 
(h)  Negotiations for a new agreement may extend beyond the June 30 expiration date of the existing agreement, and the provisions and benefits of the existing agreement shall be extended during the period of the negotiations and until the new agreement is reached, subject to the annual appropriation of monies by the City Council as provided in paragraph (e) above. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1; Ord. No. 0-8788-50) 
Sec. 12-205. - Negotiation impasses. 
(a)  All negotiation impasses not resolved by March 1 shall be subject to mediation by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. At the request of either party, the parties shall jointly notify the Service of their need for the immediate assistance of a mediator. 
(b)  All negotiation impasses not resolved by April 15 shall be subject to a fact-finding process. At the request of either party, all negotiation impasses not resolved through mediation shall jointly be submitted to fact-finding by a three (3) member board. Each party shall select its partisan member within three (3) business days following initiation of the fact-finding process. Within seven (7) business days following initiation of the fact -finding process, the two (2) partisan members shall select a neutral member, who serves as chairman. By mutual agreement of the parties these selection deadlines may be extended or waived. If the two (2) partisan members are unable to agree on the neutral member, the parties shall immediately request the American Arbitration Association to appoint the neutral member. The parties shall share equally the costs of the neutral member. 
(c)  The fact-finding board shall conduct its hearing as soon as possible. The chairman shall be responsible for the conduct of the hearing. The parties and their witnesses shall appear and give testimony and produce the books, records, and other evidence relative to or pertinent to the negotiation impasses presented to the board. The hearing may be continued at the discretion of the chairman. The hearing shall be concluded and the board's report and recommendations shall be submitted to the parties at the earliest possible opportunity. 
(d)  At any time before the submission of the board's report and recommendations to the parties, the parties may mutually resolve each of the impasses. In this event, the parties shall immediately request the board that the proceedings be terminated and the board, acting through the chairman, shall terminate the proceedings. 
(e)  The factors, among others, to be given weight by the fact-finding board in arriving at its report and recommendations shall include: 
(1)  The lawful authority of the employer; 
(2)  The financial ability of the employer to meet costs; 
(3)  The interests and welfare of the public; 
(4)  The hazards of employment, physical, education, and mental qualifications, job training and skills involved; 
(5)  A comparison of wages, hours and conditions of employment of the employees involved in the fact-finding proceeding with the wages, hours, and conditions of employment of other employees performing similar services and with other employees generally in public and private employment in comparable communities, primarily in this geographic region; 
(6)  The average consumer prices for goods and services, commonly known as the cost of living; 
(7)  The overall compensation presently received by the employees, including direct wages and fringe benefits; 
(8)  Changes in any of the foregoing circumstances during the pendency of the fact-finding hearing; 
(9)  Such other factors, not confined to the foregoing, which are normally or traditionally taken into consideration in the determination of wages, hours, and conditions of employment through voluntary collective bargaining, mediation, fact-finding, arbitration, or otherwise between the parties, in the public service or in private employment; and 
(10)  The stipulations of the parties. 
(f)  The chairman of the fact-finding board is authorized to write the report and recommendations. In the event that no two (2) members of the board agree on the content of the report and recommendations, the chairman's position shall comprise the report and recommendations. Members of the board may append dissenting opinions to the report and recommendations. 
(g)  The report and recommendations of the fact-finding board is advisory to the parties. If there is no agreement on each of the impasses within five (5) business days after the parties receive the report and recommendations, the City Manager shall file a copy of the report and recommendations with his comments with the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1; Ord. No. 0-8788-50) 
Sec. 12-206. - Grievance and arbitration procedures. 
(a)  An agreement between the employer and a labor organization shall provide a procedure for the consideration of grievances over the interpretation or application of the agreement. A negotiated grievance procedure may not cover any other matters and it shall be the exclusive procedure available to the parties and the employees in the bargaining unit for resolving grievances which fall within its coverage. However, any employee or group of employees in the bargaining unit may present such grievances to the employer and have them adjusted, without the intervention of the exclusive representative, as long as the adjustment is consistent with the terms of the agreement and the exclusive representative has been given opportunity to be present at such adjustment. 
(b)  A negotiated grievance procedure may provide for arbitration of grievances. Arbitration may be invoked only by the employer or the exclusive representative. The grievance shall be submitted to arbitration under the Voluntary Labor Arbitration Rules of the American Arbitration Association. The parties shall share equally the cost of the arbitrator's fees and expenses. The arbitrator's award shall be consistent with the authority granted the arbitrator by the agreement and the Code and Charter of the City. Questions as to whether or not a grievance is on a matter subject to the grievance procedure in an existing agreement or is subject to arbitration under the agreement, may be submitted to arbitration. 
(c)  Where the negotiated grievance procedure does not provide for arbitration of grievances, questions as to whether or not a grievance is on a matter subject to the grievance procedure in an existing agreement may be submitted in accordance with the procedures set forth in section 12-201 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-207. - Unfair labor practices. 
(a)  It shall be an unfair labor practice for the employer: 
(1)  To interfere with, restrain, or coerce an employee in the exercise of the rights guaranteed in this chapter: 
(2)  To encourage or discourage membership in a labor organization by discrimination in regard to hiring, tenure, promotion, or other conditions of employment; 
(3)  To sponsor, control, or otherwise interfere or assist with the formation or administration of any labor organization or contribute financial or other support to it; 
(4)  To discipline, discharge, or otherwise discriminate against an employee because he or she has filed charges or given testimony under this chapter; or 
(5)  To refuse to bargain collectively with the exclusively recognized representatives of his employees. 
(b)  It shall be an unfair labor practice for a labor organization: 
(1)  To interfere with, restrain, or coerce an employee in the exercise of the rights guaranteed in this chapter; 
(2)  To cause or attempt to cause the employer to coerce an employee in the exercise of the rights guaranteed in this chapter; 
(3)  To coerce, attempt to coerce, or discipline, fine, or take other economic sanction against a member of the labor organization as punishment or reprisal for, or for the purpose of hindering or impeding his work performance, his productivity, or the discharge of his or her duties owed as an employee of the City; 
(4)  To call or engage in a strike, work stoppage, or slowdown, or condone any such activity by failing to take affirmative action to prevent or stop it; 
(5)  To discriminate against an employee with regard to the terms or conditions of membership because of race, color, creed, sex, age, or national origin; 
(6)  To deny membership to any employee in the appropriate bargaining unit except for failure to meet reasonable occupational standards uniformly required for admission, or for failure to render initiation fees and dues uniformly required as a condition of acquiring and retaining membership; however, this paragraph does not preclude a labor organization from enforcing discipline in accordance with procedures under its constitution and by-laws which conform to the requirements of this chapter; or 
(7)  To refuse to bargain collectively with the employer, provided the labor organization is the exclusively recognized representative of the employees. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
Sec. 12-208. - Standards of conduct for labor organizations. 
(a)  Recognition shall only be accorded to a labor organization that is free from corrupt influences and influences opposed to basic democratic principles. 
(b)  A labor organization seeking recognition shall provide the employer with evidence that it is subject to governing requirements which contain explicit and detailed provisions calling for: 
(1)  The maintenance of democratic procedures and practices, including provisions for periodic elections to be conducted subject to recognized safeguards and provisions defining and securing the right of individual members to participation in the affairs of the organization, to fair and equal treatment under the governing rules of the organization, and to fair process in disciplinary proceedings; 
(2)  The exclusion from office in the organization of persons affiliated with totalitarian movements and persons identified with corrupt influences; 
(3)  One prohibition of business or financial interests on the part of the organization officers and agents which conflict with their duty to the organization and its members; and 
(4)  The maintenance of fiscal integrity in the conduct of the affairs of the organization, including provision for accounting and financial controls, regular financial reports or summaries to be made available to members, and the bonding for the faithful discharge of duties of each officer and agent who handles funds or other property of the labor organization. 
(Ord. No. 0-7576-1) 
ARTICLE III. - DISCUSSION OF CITY GOVERNMENTAL MATTERS BY EMPLOYEES AND OFFICERS 

Sec. 12-301. - Statement of rights; disciplinary action prohibited. 
(a)  The right of employees and officers of the City of Norman to petition the City Council or a member of the City Council or to furnish public information to the City Council, or to a committee or member thereof, may not be interfered with or denied; provided that the information is a matter of public concern (such as wasteful, fraudulent or unlawful City practices) and the information is based upon reliable sources, which includes documented, concrete facts to support the allegations. 
(b)  No supervisor or appointing authority of the City of Norman shall prohibit officers or employees of such City from discussing the operations of the City, either specifically or generally with any member of the City Council, any committee appointed by the City Council, or any City Administrative Board or Court of Law; provided that the information is a matter of public concern (such as wasteful, fraudulent or unlawful City practices) and the information is based upon reliable sources, which includes documented, concrete facts to support the allegations. 
(c)  Disciplinary actions, including, but not limited to, any direct or indirect form of discipline, any dismissal, demotion, transfer, reassignment, suspension, reprimand, admonishment, warning of possible dismissal, reduction in force, reduction in rank, reduction in status or withholding from work, shall not be taken against any employee or officer for providing public information or offering to provide public information to any member of the City Council, or any committee appointed by the City Council, or any City Administrative Board or Court of Law; provided that the information is a matter of public concern (such as wasteful, fraudulent, or unlawful City practices) and the information is based upon reliable sources, which includes documented, concrete facts to support the allegations. 
(Ord. No. 0-8788-28) 
Sec. 12-302. - Establishment of Review Board. 
(a)  There shall be established from time to time a Review Board to review complaints filed pursuant to this article. 
(b)  The Review Board shall consist of six (6) of the following, provided the requirements of subsection (c) are met: 
(1)  The Director of Personnel or his designee; 
(2)  The City Manager or his designee; 
(3)  Either a union official (if the complaining employee belongs to the union) or any other employee of the City of Norman who has worked with the City for three (3) years (if the complaining employee does not belong to the union). The appointed employee shall be selected by the complaining employee. 
(4)  The City Attorney or his designee; 
(5)  Two (2) citizens of the City agreed upon by (1), (2), (3) and (4) above. 
(c)  Substitute Review Board members. 
(1)  No department head or disciplining supervisor shall be allowed to act as a member of the Review Board if such department head or disciplining supervisor works either in the same department in which the complaining employee works or in the same department about which the transmitted information is concerned. 
(2)  In the event a Review Board Appointee is disqualified under subsection c(1), the position shall be filled by the appointment by the City Manager of a representative of another department of the City of Norman. 
(3)  Each member of the Review Board shall be allowed one (1) vote, except the City Attorney or his designee. The City Attorney or his designee shall sit on the Review Board in an advisory capacity only and shall not vote. 
(Ord. No. 0-8788-28) 
Sec. 12-303. - Complaints and review thereof. 
(a)  Employee complaints. 
(1)  Any employee or former employee aggrieved pursuant to this article may file a written request for a hearing by the Review Board within thirty (30) days of the alleged disciplinary action. The Review Board shall set such matters for hearing within ten (10) days after the filing of a request for review. 
(2)  The Review Board shall inquire into the reason for the disciplinary action. If the Review Board finds the employee in violation of the provisions of this article, the Review Board may recommend such action as it deems appropriate and as specified in section 12-304. If the Review Board finds the supervisor in violation of the provisions of this article, then the Review Board may recommend such action as deemed appropriate in section 12-304; and such a finding shall be an aggravated circumstance. 
(b)  Complaints by a supervisor or appointing authority. 
(1)  A supervisor or City Manager shall have the right to file a written request to the Review Board for review when an employee abuses the rights enumerated in this article. 
(2)  The Review Board shall inquire into whether, at the time the employee made the allegation pursuant to this article, there existed sufficient factual, verified information so that a reasonable and prudent person would believe the allegations were, in fact, true. 
(c)  Decisions by the Review Board shall be rendered in recommendation form to the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 0-8788-28) 
Sec. 12-304. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Any supervisor of the City who violates the provisions of this article by abridging the rights of the employee as set out herein shall be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including dismissal, as deemed appropriate by the City Manager. 
(b)  Any employee or officer of the City who violates the provisions of this article by disseminating or providing false or unfounded information that is detrimental to City operations shall be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including dismissal, as deemed appropriate by the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 0-8788-28) 
Sec. 12-305. - Appeal of City Manager's decision. 
    There shall be no appeal of the decision of the City Manager, except that this section shall not be construed to abridge any rights of the employers, officers or employees of the City of Norman, either in law or equity. 
(Ord. No. 0-8788-28) 
Chapter 13 - LICENSES AND OCCUPATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - ADMINISTRATIVE AND GENERAL LICENSING PROVISIONS 

Sec. 13-101. - Application for license. 
(a)  All persons required to procure a license under the provisions of this chapter shall submit an application for such license to the Clerk or his representative. 
(b)  Such application shall be upon forms provided by the Clerk, and shall be accompanied by: 
(1)  An affidavit to be sworn to by the applicant; 
(2)  A disclosure of all information necessary to comply with the applicable article of this chapter; 
(3)  Any other information which the Clerk shall find to be reasonably necessary to the fair administration of this chapter; and 
(4)  The full amount of the applicable fees. 
(c)  A license/permit under this chapter shall not be issued to an applicant that owes delinquent sales tax, Municipal Court fees or fines, utility bills, or any other amount properly due and owing to the City of Norman. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-1112-29, § 1) 
Sec. 13-102. - Display of license. 
(a)  All persons who obtain a required license under this chapter shall post and maintain such license upon the licensed premises in a conspicuous place. 
(b)  Should any insignia be issued by the Clerk for use in connection with the business premises, such insignia shall be affixed on the inside glass part of the door opening on the public way. 
(c)  All persons who obtain a required license under this chapter who have no licensed business premises shall carry such license upon their person, and such license shall be produced or exhibited when requested by any officer or official of the City. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, all vehicles required to be licensed or specially designated by the provisions of this chapter, shall have the applicable insignia affixed on the inside left rear windshield of that vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-103. - Duplicate license. 
    A duplicate license or special permit shall be issued by the Clerk to replace any license previously issued, which has been lost, stolen, defaced or destroyed without any willful conduct on the part of the licensee, upon the filing of the licensee's affidavit attesting to such fact and the payment to the Clerk of a fee of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-104. - Duties of Clerk. 
(a)  The Clerk shall collect all license fees and shall issue licenses in the name of the City to all persons who qualify under the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  The Clerk shall, with the assistance of the City Attorney and applicable advisory licensing bodies: 
(1)  Promulgate and enforce all reasonable rules and regulations necessary to the operation and enforcement of this chapter; 
(2)  Adopt all forms and prescribe the information to be given therein as to the character and other relevant matter for all necessary papers; 
(3)  Require the applicants to submit all affidavits and oaths necessary to the administration of this chapter; 
(4)  Submit all applications in a proper case to interested City officials for their endorsements thereon as to compliance by the applicant with all City regulations which they have the duty of enforcing; 
(5)  Investigate and determine the eligibility of any applicant for a license as prescribed herein; 
(6)  Examine the books and records of any applicant or licensee when reasonably necessary to the administration and enforcement of this chapter; and 
(7)  Notify any applicant of the acceptance or rejection of his application and shall, upon his refusal of any license or permit at the applicant's request, state in writing the reasons therefor and deliver them to such applicant. 
(c)  The Clerk shall keep all information furnished or secured under the authority of this chapter in strict confidence, and such information shall not be subject to public inspection or made available except to persons charged with the administration of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-105. - Duties of the licensee. 
(a)  All licensees under this chapter shall permit all reasonable inspections of his business and examination of his books by those public authorities so authorized by this chapter. 
(b)  All licensees, their agents, and employees, shall: 
(1)  Ascertain and comply with all laws and regulations applicable to such licensed businesses; 
(2)  Avoid all forbidden, improper or unnecessary practices or conditions which do or may affect the public health, morals, or welfare; 
(3)  Refrain from operating the licensed business on premises after the expiration of his license or during the period the license is revoked or suspended; 
(4)  Keep all records and books necessary to the computation of the applicable license fee and for the enforcement of this chapter. 
(c)  Except as provided in this chapter, no licensee shall loan, sell, give, or assign to any other person or allow such other person to use or display, or to destroy, damage or remove, or to have in his possession, any license or insignia which has been issued to said licensee. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-106. - Enforcement: Authority of officials. 
(a)  The Clerk, the officers of the Fire Department, Health Department, Police Department, and the Department of Planning and Community Development are authorized to conduct inspections and investigations reasonably necessary for the enforcement of this chapter. 
(b)  All such authorized persons shall have the authority to enter, with or without search warrants, at all reasonable time the premises of those: 
(1)  For which a license is required, 
(2)  For which a license was issued and which at the time of inspection is operating under such license, 
(3)  For which the license has been revoked or suspended. 
(c)  All such authorized persons inspecting licensees, their businesses, or premises shall report all violations of this chapter or of other provisions of this Code to the Clerk and the City Attorney, and shall submit such other reports as the Clerk shall order. 
(d)  Except where otherwise provided in this Code, when an inspector has reported the violation of this chapter or of any provisions of the Code, the Clerk shall issue to the affected person a provisional order to comply within five (5) days or within a reasonable time, whichever is longer. 
(e)  Any such provisional order shall be in writing, personally served or mailed by registered mail to the licensee or his agent, and shall appraise the person affected of this specific violation. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-8081-28; Ord. No. 0-9697-1) 
Sec. 13-107. - Expiration dates of licenses and permits. 
(a)  Licenses issued prior to November 14, 1974, shall expire in accordance with previous Code provisions. Thereafter, all annual licenses shall expire at midnight on the last day of March. 
(b)  All permits shall expire upon execution of the act or activity for which the permit was issued, or at the expiration time noted on the permit, whichever first occurs. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8)

No. 0-0001-66; Ord. No. 0-0102-29; Ord. No. 0-0506-65; Ord. No. 0-0809-18, § 6; Ord. No. 0-0910-41, § 1; Ord. No. 0-1213-34, § 14; Ord. No. 0-1314-30, § 1; Ord. No. 0-1314-47, § 1; Ord. No. 0-1516-18, § 7; Ord. No. 0-1718-46, § 1; Ord. No. 0-1819-4, § 1; Ord. No. 0-1819-17, § 1) 
Sec. 13-109. - Form of license. 
    Each license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall state upon its face: 
(1)  The name of the licensee and any other name under which such business is to be conducted, 
(2)  The kind and address of each business so licensed, 
(3)  The amount of the applicable license fee, 
(4)  Such other information as the Clerk shall determine. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-9697-52) 
Sec. 13-110. - Nonapproval of license. 
(a)  The Clerk shall, upon disapproving any application submitted under the provisions of this Code, retain up to twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or ten (10) percent, whichever is greater, of those fees paid in advance by the person so tendering that fee, provided the applicant is not otherwise indebted to the City, in which case those fees may be used to offset that indebtedness. 
(b)  When the issuance of a license is denied and any action is instituted by the applicant to compel its issuance, such applicant shall not engage in the business for which the license was refused, unless a license be issued to him pursuant to a judgment ordering the same. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-111. - Nonendorsement. 
    No payment or receipt of payment of any license or permit shall be construed or used in any manner by any person as an official endorsement by the City of that person, his activity, or the thing licensed or permitted. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-112. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person, firm, or corporation convicted of violating any provision of this chapter, or of failing to act or comply with the provisions of this chapter, shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) or by imprisonment not to exceed sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(b)  Each day that a violation or failure to comply exists shall constitute a separate and distinct offense, and any one (1) or more of such offenses may be set out in any complaint or information filed. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-8283-05; Ord. No. 0-8384-23; Ord. No. 0-9596-45; Ord. No. 0-9900-11; Ord. No. 0-0405-26; Ord. No. 0-0506-10) 
Sec. 13-113. - Proration of license fees. 
(a)  Any application for a license renewal filed after November 14, 1974, for a period extending to March 31, 1976, and involving less than twelve (12) months, may be prorated. 
(b)  Applications filed less than six (6) months prior to the last day of March of any year shall pay one-half (1/2) of the fee prescribed in section 13-108 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-114. - Qualifications of applicants. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by this chapter, applicants for licenses shall be: 
(1)  Of good moral character; 
(2)  Not in default under the provisions of this chapter; 
(3)  Not indebted or obligated in any manner to the City; 
(4)  In compliance with the applicable zoning regulations regarding the business or activity being licensed. [1] 
(b)  The Clerk shall make his determination as to the good moral character of the applicant by consideration of: 
(1)  The applicant's convictions, the reasons therefor, and the demeanor of the applicant subsequent to his release; 
(2)  The applicant's history, whether such person in previously operating in this or another jurisdiction under a license has had such license revoked or suspended, the reasons therefor, and the demeanor of the applicant subsequent to such action; and 
(3)  Such other facts relevant to the general personal history of the applicant as the Clerk shall find necessary to a fair determination of the eligibility of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning, Ch. 22. 

Sec. 13-115. - Rebates on licenses. 
(a)  Except as herein provided, no rebate or refund of any license fee, or part thereof shall be made by reason of the nonuse of such license or by reason of a change of location or business rendering the use of such license ineffective. 
(b)  The Clerk shall have the authority to refund a license fee or prorated portion thereof where the license fee was collected through an error. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-116. - Receipts. 
(a)  Whenever a license cannot be issued at the time the application for the license is made, the Clerk shall issue a receipt to the applicant for the money paid in advance. 
(b)  Such receipt shall not be construed as any approval by the Clerk for the issuance of a license, nor shall it entitle or authorize the applicant to open or maintain any business contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-117. - Renewals. 
    All applicants for the renewal of a license shall submit an application for such license to the Clerk as required in section 13-101 of this Code, any supplemental information required by the Clerk, and the applicable license or renewal fee. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-118. - Revocation, suspension. 
    All licenses or permits issued pursuant to this chapter are subject to revocation or suspension by either the Clerk or the applicable licensing or examining board, based upon violations of the conditions of that license or permit, or upon conviction of violations of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-119. - Transfers of licenses and permits. 
    No licensee shall have the right to transfer his licenses to another person. Permits issued to licensed contractors may be transferred to qualified contractors upon the written request by the property owner. A fee for the transfer of a permit in good standing shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-0506-65) 
ARTICLE II. - AIR-CONDITIONING, HEATING AND REFRIGERATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Air Conditioning, Heating and Refrigeration Board, § 4-201 et seq.; building regulations concerning air conditioning, refrigeration and heating, § 5-201 et seq. 

Sec. 13-201. - Bonds required of contractors. 
    Bonds shall be required in the amount and consistent with the requirements of the State of Oklahoma. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-0506-65) 
Sec. 13-202. - Licensing for contractors and journeymen. 
(a)  No person shall install, service, alter, or repair on consumer premises any systems of air conditioning or heating or refrigeration as a contractor or journeyman in that trade without having first obtained a license as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  No corporation, partnership or business shall engage in the installation or servicing, alteration or repairing on consumer premises any systems of air conditioning or heating or refrigeration without an appropriate contractor as an active officer of the corporation or an active member of the firm; and the name and address of such contractor and the name and address of the corporation or firm shall be certified and registered with the Clerk. 
(c)  No exception is provided that will allow an owner occupant of a single-family dwelling to perform air conditioning, heating or refrigeration work on the dwelling occupied by that owner occupant or owner occupant's immediate family. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-7677-20; Ord. No. 0-0506-65) 
Sec. 13-203. - Identification of vehicles. 
(a)  Except for passenger automobiles, all vehicles used in any manner by a contractor or other person, corporation or firm engaged in the installation, servicing, alteration, or repairing of systems of air conditioning, or heating or refrigeration, while such vehicles are used in the scope of that business, shall be identified by having conspicuously printed on the side and the rear of such vehicles, the number of the State of Oklahoma license issued to the contractor, corporation or firm. 
(b)  All such numbers shall be displayed as prescribed by the State of Oklahoma. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-0506-65) 
Sec. 13-204. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  Except as herein provided, no contractor shall employ or hire anyone to work at, or permit any person to work at, installing, servicing, altering, or repairing on consumer premises any systems of air conditioning or heating or refrigeration, except that person be a licensed journeyman, or that person be an apprentice registered with the State of Oklahoma and that apprentice performs such work under the personal supervision of a licensed journeyman. 
(b)  Except for those persons also holding a gas fitters license, no contractor, his agents or employees shall install, alter, or repair on consumer premises, any gas lines or gas pipes connecting to any systems of air conditioning or heating or refrigeration. 
(c)  Except for those persons also holding a gas fitters license, no contractor, his agents or employees shall install, alter, or repair on consumer premises any drains or other plumbing used in connection with any systems of air conditioning or heating or refrigeration. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-0506-65) 
ARTICLE III. - AMBULANCE SERVICE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Discrimination in public accommodations, § 7-106. 

Sec. 13-301. - Sole-provider ambulance system. 
(a)  The emergency medical service operated by the City of Norman, or its assignee, shall be the sole provider for all of the ambulance service, both emergency and nonemergency, within the corporate city limits and shall hold the City's exclusive ambulance license, as authorized by State statute. 
(b)  All ambulance calls originating within the corporate city limits of the City must utilize the emergency medical service of the City of Norman or its assignee. 
(c)  All ambulance services operating outside of the corporate city limits of the City must first obtain authorization from the emergency medical service dispatch prior to operating within the City of Norman. 
(Ord. No. 0-9192-12; Ord. No. 0-9697-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-9192-12, § 1, adopted Aug. 27, 1991, amended § 13-301 to read as set forth herein. Formerly, § 13-301 pertained to additional requirements for applications for licenses and derived from Ord. No. 0-7475-8. 
Sec. 13-302. - License issuance. 
    No municipal license shall be required, however, the state licensure standards for emergency medical services as set forth by State statute shall be recognized as the minimum standards for emergency medical services. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-9192-12) 
ARTICLE IV. - BEEKEEPING (APIARY) 

Sec. 13-401. - Permit required. 
    Except in those areas zoned A-1, A-2, and R-E, no person shall keep or maintain any colony or hive of bees without complying with all provisions of this article and without having obtained a permit as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-402. - Colonies restricted. 
    No person shall keep or maintain more than one (1) colony of bees per two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet of lot area. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-403. - Hives. 
    No person shall keep or maintain bee colonies in other than movable frame hives, and mature colonies shall be housed in two (2) full-depth brood chambers. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-404. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-9596-54, § 1, adopted June 11, 1996, deleted § 13-404 in its entirety. Formerly, § 13-404 pertained to registration of beekeeping operations and derived from Ord. No. 0-7475-8. 
Sec. 13-405. - Setback requirements. 
    No person shall locate colonies of bees closer than thirty-five (35) feet of any property line, except: 
(1)  When those colonies are situated at least eight (8) feet above adjacent ground level; or 
(2)  When situated less than six (6) feet above adjacent ground level and behind a solid fence, wall, dense evergreen hedge or effective equivalent having a height of not less than six (6) feet and parallel to each property line within thirty-five (35) feet of the hive. Such fence shall extend at least thirty (30) feet beyond the hive in both directions or the full length of the property line to which the fence is parallel, whichever is the lesser. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-406. - Water sources. 
    No person shall keep or maintain any colony of bees without providing a fresh water source on his lot during all periods that the bees fly from the hives. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
ARTICLE V. - CHILD CARE ESTABLISHMENTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Children's Rights Coordinating Commission, § 4-1701 et seq.; discrimination in public accommodations, § 7-106; transportation of children by day care centers, § 20-545. 

Sec. 13-501. - Child care establishment, definition. 
(a)  Except as hereinafter provided, a "child care establishment" is any place, home, or institution which receives more than eight (8) children under the age of sixteen (16) years, who are not of common parentage, for care apart from their parents, legal guardians or custodians, when such care is received for regular periods of time for compensation. 
(b)  Places, homes, or institutions excepted from the above definition are: 
(1)  Those public and private schools organized, operated or approved under the laws of Oklahoma and regulated by the State Department of Education; 
(2)  Those where custody of the children has been fixed by a court of competent jurisdiction; 
(3)  Those where children are related by blood or marriage within the third degree of the custodial person; 
(4)  Those public or private institutions caring for children while the parents, legal guardians or custodians are attending services, meetings, classes, or otherwise engaging in that institution's activities, to the extent such care and custody does not exceed four (4) hours at any one (1) time. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-502. - Licenses, exceptions. 
(a)  Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall open, operate or maintain a child care establishment without having previously complied with applicable provisions of Chapter 22 of this Code and without having obtained a valid license from the City for such activity. 
(b)  Persons excepted from the above licensing requirements are those operating child care establishments having the license or approval of the State Department of Institutions, Social & Rehabilitation Services, and operating such under their rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-503. - Responsibilities of the Director of the Health Department. 
(a)  The Director of the Health Department or his designated representative shall: 
(1)  Receive all applications from the City Clerk; 
(2)  Inquire and investigate as to the character, fitness and reputation of the applicants; 
(3)  Inquire as to the suitability of accommodations and their compliance with the building, safety and fire codes of the City; 
(4)  By writing, approve or disapprove applications, and cite reasons thereon in the event of disapproval; 
(5)  Establish and promulgate such rules, regulations, and standards for City licensed child-care establishment, so long as such do not conflict with the Code of the City, and are necessary and reasonable to: 
[a]  Safeguard the health and physical, mental and moral safety of the children cared for and of the staff; 
[b]  Provide adequate accommodations and staff for the care, supervision, discipline, recreation, and proper nurture and training of the children cared for; 
[c]  Insure a directorship and staff of such character, personality, training, and experience as to enable them to understand the problems of the children in the child-care establishment; providing the proper care, guidance, discipline, planning of programs and cooperation with parents in order to insure the proper nurture and development of the children cared for; 
[d]  Provide proper and adequate public liability insurance in respect to the child-care establishment or to the transportation of children to or from such establishment; 
[e]  Facilitate the inspection of child-care establishments under the terms of this article; 
[f]  Govern the procedure to be followed in the revocation or suspension of licenses hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-504. - Conflicting rules and regulations. 
    The provisions of chapters 5 and 9 of this Code shall control over any rules and regulations of the Department of Institutions, Social & Rehabilitation Services pertaining to child-care establishments which are in conflict with such chapters. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-505. - Inspections. 
    All child care establishments shall be open to the inspection of the Director of the Health Department, the Director of the Public Works Department, the Fire Marshal or their designated representatives, so long as such inspections are made during reasonable hours of the establishment's operations. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-506. - Zoning ordinances. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall authorize the operation, maintenance or approval of any child-care establishment in any location or upon any premises in violation of chapter 22 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
ARTICLE VI. - DRY CLEANING ESTABLISHMENTS, SELF-SERVICE 

Sec. 13-601. - Attendant required on duty. 
    No person shall operate, maintain, or permit the operation of any coin-operated or self-service dry-cleaning machines for use by the public or patrons of such, or where such patrons or customers are allowed to do any dry-cleaning themselves by placing in and/or removing clothing or garments from such machines, unless a qualified attendant be on duty and present at all times that the establishment is open for business. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-602. - Duties of attendants. 
    The attendant must actually and actively supervise the use of any and all coin-operated or self-service dry cleaning machines, and shall give necessary instruction to patrons or customers respecting the safe and proper use thereof. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-603. - Qualifications of attendants. 
    Any person serving as an attendant in a self-service dry-cleaning establishment must be: 
(1)  Of legal age. 
(2)  Trained and qualified in the operation of such dry-cleaning machines, 
(3)  Knowledgeable of the hazards involved in the use of such machines and the necessary precautions to be taken by persons using those machines, 
(4)  Knowledgeable of any emergency measures required to be taken in the event of such machine's breakdown, or in the event of the escape of any solvent, liquid or gas used therein. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
ARTICLE VII. - ELECTRICIANS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Electricians Board, § 4-701 et seq.; electrical code, § 5-401 et seq. 

Sec. 13-701. - Bonds required of contractors. 
    Bonds shall be required in the amount and consistent with the requirements of the State of Oklahoma. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-0506-65) 
Sec. 13-702. - Licensing for contractors. 
(a)  No person shall install, alter, maintain or repair any electric conductors or equipment as a contractor in that trade without having first obtained a license as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  No corporation, partnership or business shall engage in the installation or servicing, alteration or repairing of any electrical conductors or equipment without an appropriate contractor as an active officer of the corporation or an active member of the firm; and the name and address of such contractor and the name and address of the corporation or firm shall be certified and registered with the Clerk. 
(c)  No exception is provided that will allow an owner occupant of a single-family dwelling to perform electrical work on the dwelling occupied by that owner occupant or owner occupant's immediate family. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-0506-65; Ord. No. 0-1314-30, § 2) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 0-1314-30, adopted June 24, 2014, changed the title of § 13-702, from "Licensing for contractors and journeymen" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 13-703. - Prohibited acts. 
    Except as herein provided, no master shall employ or hire anyone to work at, or permit any person to work at, installing, servicing, altering, or repairing any electrical conductors or equipment, except that person be a licensed journeyman, or that person be an apprentice registered with the State of Oklahoma and that apprentice performs such work under the personal supervision of a licensed journeyman. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-0506-65) 
Sec. 13-704. - Identification of vehicles. 
(a)  Except for passenger automobiles, all vehicles used in any manner by a contractor or other person, corporation or firm engaged in the installation, servicing, alteration or repairing of any electrical conductors or equipment, while such vehicles are used in the scope of that business, shall be identified by having conspicuously printed on the side and rear of such vehicles, the number of the State of Oklahoma license issued to the contractor, corporation or firm. 
(b)  All such numbers shall be displayed as prescribed by the State of Oklahoma. 
(Ord. No. 0-8182-35; Ord. No. 0-0506-65) 
ARTICLE VIII. - FOOD SERVICES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Discrimination in public accommodations, § 7-106; utility deposit for food establishments, § 21-104(a)(5). 

Sec. 13-801. - Code provisions adopted. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, the current edition of the Oklahoma State Department of Health, Protective Health Services, Food Service Establishment Regulations (hereinafter referred to as the Food Service Establishment Regulations) is hereby incorporated into the Code of the City, with the same force and effect as if fully set out in this subsection. 
(b)  The Food Service Establishment Regulations shall not become effective until at least three (3) copies thereof have been filed in the office of the City Clerk for examination by the public. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-8283-39; Ord. No. 0-0102-29; Ord. No. 0-0506-65) 
Sec. 13-802. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-0506-65, § 2, adopted June 16, 2006, deleted § 13-802 in its entirety. Former 13-802 pertained to code provisions deleted and derived from Ord. No. 0-7475-8 and Ord. No. 8283-39. 
Sec. 13-803. - Code provisions terminology. 
    Whenever the term "Municipality of ___________" is used in the Food Service Establishment Regulations, it refers to the City of Norman. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-8283-39; Ord. No. 0-0506-65) 
Sec. 13-804. - Drive-in restaurants: Deposit of waste materials. 
    All persons owning, operating, or in charge of a drive-in restaurant shall require all employees of that restaurant to pick up and deposit all trash and waste materials found on the premises, and to pick up and deposit all trash and waste materials found lying outside the premises, the drive-in parking lot, and any portion of any street or alley adjoining that restaurant not less than once every twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-805. - Drive-in restaurants: Receptacles for waste materials. 
(a)  All persons owning, operating, or in charge of a drive-in restaurant shall provide the premises with a number of adequate receptacles for waste material, as follows: 
(1)  One (1) receptacle shall be provided for each fifteen hundred (1500) square feet of parking space, or per each five (5) automobile parking spaces, whichever results in the greatest number of receptacles. 
(2)  In no event shall there be less than three (3) receptacles provided. 
(3)  Two (2) receptacles shall be so placed on the premises so that patrons of that restaurant may drive by them and place waste materials therein. 
(b)  All receptacles provided for the drive-in shall be manufactured of plastic or metal, constructed in such manner so that trash deposited therein will not escape, and shall be fixed with hinged or swinging doors at the top. 
(c)  Near each receptacle, the person owning, operating, or in charge of the drive-in restaurant shall place in conspicuous places about the premises, signs with lettering not less than three (3) inches in height, which state: IT IS UNLAWFUL TO THROW TRASH ON GROUND. PLEASE DEPOSIT REFUSE IN RECEPTACLES PROVIDED. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-806. - Food handling: Diseased persons not to be employed. 
    No person shall work or permit or allow any other person to work in a bakery, cafe, meat market, restaurant, or other place where food is handled or served, whether for compensation or not, when that person is infected with, suffering from, or is a carrier of any contagious disease. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8) 
Sec. 13-807. - Food handling: Work permits required. 
    No person shall work, or permit any other person to work in a bakery, cafe, meat market, restaurant, or other place where food is handled or served, whether for compensation or not, unless that person possesses a current and unrevoked permit from the Cleveland County Health Officer. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-0506-65) 
Sec. 13-808. - Health Officer's duties and powers. 
(a)  The Cleveland County Health Officer may require any physical, medical and laboratory examinations of any applicants or holders of food handling work permits, as he deems necessary to insure compliance with the health laws of the State of Oklahoma and the Code of the City. 
(b)  Prior to the approval of food handling work permit, the Cleveland County Health Officer shall give the applicant such instruction as he may deem necessary, in the approved methods of sanitation and food handling applicable to the business in which the applicant intends to work, and shall further instruct such applicants as to the applicable laws and Code provisions relating to such work. 
(c)  The Cleveland County Health Officer may periodically issue such orders and regulations relating to the sanitary practices of food handling as he deems necessary to protect the public health of the community; and such orders and regulations shall be in writing, maintained on file in his office, open to inspection by the public and shall after publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the City, have the same force and effect as if fully set out in this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-8; Ord. No. 0-0506-65) 
Sec. 13-809. - License required. 
(a)  An annual license shall be issued by the City Clerk following approval of such by the Fire Marshal, Planning Department, Cleveland County Health Authority and City Clerk. 
(b)  A person desiring to operate a temporary food service establishment may apply for either a thirty-day or a one hundred eighty-day temporary license at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to any sales at said establishment. This temporary license shall be issued by the City Clerk following approval of such application by the Cleveland County Health Authority and City Clerk. The temporary license may be renewed for an additional one hundred eighty (180) days following approval by the Cleveland County Health Authority and City Clerk. 
(c)  There shall be two (2) types of licenses issued as follows: 
(1)  Fixed Temporary Food Service License. This license shall be for temporary food service businesses operating at a fixed location for a maximum of one hundred eighty (180) days. This license may not be renewed for an additional one hundred eighty (180) days at the same location. These food service businesses must comply with all provisions of the City of Norman Zoning Code. 
(2)  Mobile Temporary Food Service License. This license shall be for facilities that are vehicle mounted and are readily moveable. 
(Ord. No. 0-8283-39; Ord. No. 0-0506-65; Ord. No. 0-1011-18, § 1) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 0-1011-18, adopted April 12, 2011, changed the title of § 13-809 from "Annual license required" to "License required." 
Sec. 13-810. - Application procedure for temporary food license. 
(a)  Contents of application. Applicants for a permit under this article must file with the City Clerk a (verified) sworn application in writing on a form to be furnished by the City Clerk, which shall give the following information: 
(1)  Name and description of applicant. 
(2)  Address. 
(3)  Brief description of business, goods to be sold, location desired. 
(4)  Time period for which applicant wishes to do business. 
(5)  License number and description of vehicle to be used, if any. 
(6)  Verification that applicant is bonded as group II vendor by the State Tax Commission or other proof that sales tax has been or is being paid on the merchandise sold or to be sold, if applicable. 
(7)  Proof that a county health permit has been obtained. 
(8)  At time of filing, fee as provided in Section 13-812 shall be paid to the City Clerk. 
(9)  Each applicant, if the applicant does not operate a fixed, permanent restaurant within the City of Norman, shall file with the application a certificate of insurance from the appropriate insurer that the applicant has general liability and vehicular insurance in the amount required by the State of Oklahoma. 
(b)  Review of application. 
(1)  The City Clerk shall review the application to ensure: 
a.  That applicant is aware of his responsibility to collect and pay sales tax and that applicant is properly registered with the Oklahoma Tax Commission. If applicant is not properly registered with the Oklahoma Tax Commission, the permit will not be issued. 
b.  That the chosen location for issuance of a Fixed Temporary Food Service License is commercially zoned and does not extend onto the public right-of-way. 
c.  That the applicant's business operation will not obstruct a safe line of sight from any street or private drive used to exit the subject property, or cause other sight-distance related problems. 
d.  That Chapter 18, "City of Norman Sign Code," Ordinance No. 0-7879-10, is to be properly complied with during applicant's business activity. 
e.  That applicant's business operations will not reduce the required off-street parking of the host business. 
f.  That a valid county health permit is obtained. 
(2)  Within seven (7) days after receipt of the application, the City Clerk shall either approve or disapprove of the application. 
a.  If the application is approved, the Clerk shall issue the permit within three (3) days after the approval. 
b.  If the application is not approved, the City Clerk must state with specificity the reason(s) for nonapproval and the City Clerk shall notify the applicant within three (3) days after nonapproval. Proper mailing to the address shown on the application shall be adequate notification to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 0-1011-18, § 2) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 0-1011-18, adopted April 12, 2011, amended the Code by adding §§ 13-810-13-813. Section 3 of said ordinance renumbered former § 13-810 as § 13-814. 
Sec. 13-811. - Conditions of permit issuance. 
(a)  All temporary food vendors must have the permission of the property owner prior to operating a temporary food vending unit on the subject property. 
(b)  No mobile temporary food vendor may stop for longer than twelve (12) hours at a single location or address in a twenty-four-hour period. A single location or address shall include a single parking lot shared by multiple businesses. 
(1)  This section shall not apply to food sales at events that are not open to the general public or are sponsored, catered, or hosted by a business or group. 
(2)  This section shall not apply on University of Oklahoma home football game days. 
(c)  Mobile temporary food vendors may not sell food on public right-of-way except for a brief stop for point of sale. For purposes of this section, public right-of-way means any street or highway and property adjacent to streets and highways which is dedicated to public use and over which the Federal, State or municipal government, or any agency, department or subdivision thereof, exercises control and dominion; or any bridge, alley, sidewalk, pedestrian way, stairs or elevator which is dedicated to public use and over which the Federal, State or municipal government, or any agency, department or subdivision thereof, exercises control and dominion. 
(Ord. No. 0-1011-18, § 2; Ord. No. 0-1112-9, § 2) 
Sec. 13-812. - Permit issuance. 
(a)  Permits shall be issued by the City Clerk. 
(b)  A permit must be issued not less than twenty-four (24) hours prior to any actual selling activity by the applicant.
