(b)  Should a divided street have roadways thirty (30) or more feet apart, then each crossing of such a divided street by another street shall be regarded as a separate intersection. 
(c)  The junction of an alley with a street or highway shall not constitute an intersection. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8485-84; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-115. - Loading zone. 
    A loading zone is any space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-116. - Minibike. 
    A minibike is a motor vehicle or motor-driven cycle having less than a ten-inch rim, or less than a forty-inch wheel base, or less than a twenty-five-inch seat height. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8485-84; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-117. - Motorcycle or motor scooter. 
    A motorcycle or a motor scooter is any motor vehicle designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8485-84; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-118. - Motor vehicle. 
    A motor vehicle is any vehicle which is self-propelled. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-119. - Non-motor vehicle. 
    A non-motor vehicle is any vehicle which is not self-propelled, such as a bicycle, a buckboard, a pushcart, etc. 
(Ord No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-120. - Park, parking. 
    To park or parking is the standing of a vehicle occupied or unoccupied otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually loading or unloading merchandise or passengers. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48, § 5) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-121. - Pedestrian. 
    A pedestrian is a person afoot. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-122. - Private road or driveway. 
    A private road or driveway is a way or place privately owned and used by the owner for vehicular travel, as well as by only those individuals having express or implied permission from the owner. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-123. - Right-of-way. 
    A right-of-way is the right of one vehicle or pedestrian to proceed in a lawful manner in preference to another vehicle or pedestrian approaching under such circumstances of direction, speed, and/or proximity as to give rise to danger of collision unless one grants precedence to the other. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-124. - Roadway. 
(a)  A roadway is that portion of a street which is improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic, exclusive of the shoulder or berm. 
(b)  In the event that a street includes two (2) or more such separate portions, the terms shall refer to such portion separately, and not to all such portions collectively. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-125. - School zones. 
(a)  A school zone is that portion of a street adjacent to a school and marked so indicating it to be such a zone. 
(b)  A school crossing zone is that portion of a street designed to allow safe passage of school-bound pedestrians across the street and distinctly marked to indicate it is such a zone. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8485-84; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-126. - Stop. 
(a)  To stop, when prohibited, is the complete cessation of a vehicle's movement, even momentarily, except: 
(1)  When necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic; or 
(2)  When in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic device. 
(b)  To stop, when required, is the complete cessation of a vehicle's movement. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-127. - Stand. 
    To stand is the halting of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than for the purpose of and while actually engaged in receiving or discharging passengers. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-128. - Street. 
    A street is the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-129. - Through streets. 
    A through street is a street or portion thereof upon which vehicular traffic is given preferential right-of-way, and at the entrance to which vehicular traffic from intersecting streets is required to come to a stop before entering or crossing, pursuant to signs properly erected as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-130. - Traffic. 
    Traffic is that flow of pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles and other conveyances, either singly or together, while using any street for purposes of travel. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-131. - Traffic control device. 
    A traffic control device is any sign, signal, marking or apparatus consistent with this chapter, which is placed by proper authority for the purposes of guiding, regulating, or warning traffic. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-132. - Vehicle. 
    A vehicle is a device within which, or by which a person or property may be transported, or drawn upon a street, except those devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-133. - Safety zones. 
    The area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is marked or indicated by adequate signs to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. 
(Ord. No. 0-8485-84; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-134. - Mopeds and motorized bicycles. 
    A motorized bicycle or moped is any vehicle having fully operative pedals for propulsion by human power, an automatic transmission and a motor with a cylinder capacity not exceeding fifty (50) cubic centimeters, which produce no more than two (2) brake horsepower, and is capable of propelling the vehicle at a maximum design speed of not more than thirty (30) miles per hour on level ground. 
(Ord. No. 0-8485-84; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
Sec. 20-135. - Sidewalks. 
    A sidewalk is that paved portion of a street between the curb or lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. 0-8485-84; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-113. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 20-201. - City Council authority. 
    The City Council shall have the sole authority to determine and designate: 
(1)  Any street or part thereof as a through street; 
(2)  Any street, alley, or part thereof as a one-way street; 
(3)  Truck routes through the City. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-202. - City Manager authority. 
    The City Manager or his designated representatives shall have the authority to: 
(1)  Designate any street or part thereof where angle parking will be permitted; 
(2)  Place and maintain bicycle lanes or routes; 
(3)  Designate bus stops, bus stands, taxicab stands, and any stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles on public streets, in such places and numbers as the Manager determines to be of greatest benefit and convenience to the public; 
(4)  Place and maintain crosswalks at intersections; 
(5)  Designate curb loading zones or handicapped parking zones; 
(6)  Restrict the direction of movement on streets, any lane thereon, or part thereof during certain designated hours; 
(7)  Mark traffic lanes upon the roadway of any street where an alignment of traffic is deemed necessary; 
(8)  Prohibit parking: 
[a]  Adjacent to schools; 
[b]  On narrow streets; 
[c]  On the left hand side of any one-way street; 
[d]  Near hazardous or congested places, so long as not to exceed one hundred (100) feet in length; 
(9)  Designate any street or part thereof where parking meters shall be installed, the type and the time limitations of those meters; 
(10)  Place and maintain safety zones for the protection of pedestrians; 
(11)  Restrict right, left or U-turns at any intersection, or the period during which such shall be prohibited; 
(12)  Place and maintain any and all traffic control adjacent to any street or intersection which may be required by this chapter, State law, Council resolution, City Manager action, or which the City Manager may deem necessary to adequately regulate, guide or warn either traffic or pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-203. - Enforcement responsibility. 
    The City Police Department is primarily responsible for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 0-9394-48, § 6, adopted August 9, 1994, deleted § 20-203 and renumbered §§ 20-204-20-206 as §§ 20-203-20-205 and § 20-209 as § 20-206. Prior to such deletion, § 20-203 pertained to bicycle licenses and derived from Ord. No. 0-7273-67. 
Sec. 20-204. - Exceptions permitted in emergencies. 
    Notwithstanding any provisions of this chapter, officers of the City Police Department may direct traffic as the conditions may require: 
(1)  In the event of a fire or other emergency; 
(2)  To expedite traffic; or 
(3)  To safeguard pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-203. 
Sec. 20-205. - Parade or procession permits. 
    No person participating in any funeral procession or parade containing more than five (5) cars or twenty (20) people shall occupy, march or proceed along any street without there having been a permit for such activity previously issued by the Chief of Police. 
    In the event that a police escort is requested or is required, there shall be a five-dollar permit fee and a thirty-five-dollar escort charge. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8990-1; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-203. 
Sec. 20-206. - Regulations. 
(a)  The Police Chief, with the approval of the City Manager, shall make such regulations as necessary to effectuate the provisions of this chapter and their enforcement. 
(b)  The Police Chief may also make and enforce temporary and experimental regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions, so long as such regulations remain in effect no more than ninety (90) days. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-203. 
Sec. 20-207. - Reports. 
    The City Police Department shall annually prepare for the City Manager a traffic report containing: 
(1)  The number of traffic accidents, the number of persons killed, the number of persons injured, and other pertinent traffic accident data; 
(2)  The number of traffic accidents investigated and other pertinent data on the safety activities of the police; 
(3)  The plans and recommendations of the divisions for future traffic safety activities. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-9394-48, § 6, adopted Aug. 9, 1994, deleted § 20-207 and renumbered § 20-210 as § 20-207. Prior to such deletion, § 20-207 pertained to preventive measures studies and derived from Ord. No. 0-7273-67. 
Sec. 20-208. - Traffic citations. 
(a)  The form of the traffic citation shall be as prescribed and approved jointly by the Presiding Judge of the Municipal Criminal Court and the Chief of Police. 
(b)  Upon the issuance of a traffic citation to an alleged violator of this chapter, the original and two (2) duplicate copies of the citation shall be delivered to the records division of the Police Department. 
(c)  Once issued, a traffic citation shall be disposed of only by trial in the Municipal Criminal Court or by other official action of a judge of that court. 
(d)  No police officer or any other person shall dispose of, alter, deface, cancel or solicit the cancellation of any traffic citation, or copy thereof, or the record of such issuance or the disposition of that citation, or any complaint or warrant arising therefrom. 
(e)  No person shall violate his written promise to appear given to an officer upon the issuance of a traffic citation regardless of the disposition of the charge for which such citation was originally issued. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-9394-48, § 6, adopted Aug. 9, 1994, deleted § 20-208 and renumbered §§ 20-211-20-113 as § 20-208-20-210. Prior to such deletion, § 20-208 pertained to maintenance of records by police department and derived from Ord. No. 0-7273-67 and Ord. No. 0-7576-50. 
Cross reference- Citations for parking violations and moving violations, §§ 14-311, 14-312. 
Sec. 20-209. - Traffic direction. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, officers of the City Police Department may direct all traffic by voice, hand, or signal in conformance with this chapter. 
(b)  Officers of the City Fire Department, when at the a scene of a fire, may direct any traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity. 
(c)  No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with the lawful order or direction of a police or fire department official. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-208. 
Sec. 20-210. - Penalties. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, any person convicted of violating the provisions of any section or subsection of this chapter shall be punished by a monetary fine in an amount not less than thirty-five dollars ($35.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(b)  Person convicted of violating the provisions of the following sections of this chapter shall be punished by a monetary fine in an amount of not less fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment: 
(1)  Section 20-301. 
(2)  Section 20-519. 
(3)  Section 20-525. 
(4)  Section 20-526. 
(5)  Section 20-527. 
(6)  Section 20-531. 
(7)  Section 20-542. 
(8)  Section 20-543. 
(c)  No person charged with the violation of section 20-509(a) of this Code shall be convicted if that person produces in open Court an operator's or chauffeur's license theretofore issued to him and valid at the time of the issuance of the citation and/or arrest. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the above subsections, the Court may impose costs in addition to any monetary fine and/or imprisonment. 
(e)  Any person convicted of violation of section 20-607 shall be punished by a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(f)  Any person convicted of violation of section 20-608 shall be punished by a fine of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(g)  Any person convicted of violation of section 20-509(c) shall be punished by a monetary fine in an amount not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(h)  Any person convicted of violation of section 20-548 shall be punished by a fine of seventy dollars ($70.00) and court costs. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-7374-57; Ord. No. 0-7778-62; Ord. No. 0-7879-18; Ord. No. 0-8081-35; Ord. No. 0-8283-05; Ord. No. 0-8384-23; Ord. No. 0-8788-16; Ord. No. 0-9091-6; Ord. No. 0-9192-26; Ord. No. 0-9394-48; Ord. No. 0-9596-45; Ord. No. 0-9900-11; Ord. No. 0-0304-11; Ord. No. 0-0405-26; Ord. No. 0-0506-10) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-208. 
Cross reference- Administrative payment of fine for traffic violations in lieu of court appearance, § 14-310. 
Secs. 20-211-20-213. - Reserved. 
Sec. 20-214. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-8485-84, § 19, adopted July 9, 1985, repealed § 20-214, pertaining to deferred sentencing for minors derived from Ord. No. 0-7273-67. 
ARTICLE III. - ACCIDENTS 

Sec. 20-301. - Duties of drivers involved in accidents. 
(a)  All drivers involved in an accident, whether with another vehicle, private or public property, a pedestrian or singly, shall: 
(1)  Immediately bring their vehicle to a stop; 
(2)  Render all reasonable assistance to any injured individuals, taking all reasonable steps to secure immediate medical attention for such injured person; 
(3)  Inform the police of the occurrence and location of the accident; 
(4)  Exchange names and addresses with the other driver (if applicable), vehicle registration numbers, license tag numbers, driver's license numbers, and the names and addresses of any passengers involved. 
(b)  Should the accident involve an unattended vehicle on private or public property, the driver shall attempt to locate the owner, and if such owner cannot be located after a reasonable inquiry, the driver shall post notice in a conspicuous place on the vehicle or property. Such notice shall contain his name and address, his driver's license number and license tag number, and the circumstances of the accident. 
(c)  After having complied with the appropriate above subsection, the driver may leave the scene of any accident if: 
(1)  Released by an officer of the City Police Department; or 
(2)  Such driver is required to make an immediate emergency run to the hospital for medical treatment of any person involved in the accident; or 
(3)  No person is either injured or killed and the total apparent damage to any one vehicle or other property involved in the accident is less than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-7576-33; Ord. No. 0-8485-84; Ord. No. 0-9900-35) 
Sec. 20-302. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-9394-48, § 7, adopted Aug. 9, 1994, amended the Code by deleting § 20-302. Formerly, § 20-302 pertained to accident reports and derived from Ord. No. 0-7273-67. 
Sec. 20-303. - Reports confidential. 
(a)  All reports filed pursuant to section 20-302 of this Code are not of public record; and shall be released only to that person making that report, his insurance agent, their respective agents, or the City Legal Department; and shall not be used as evidence in any civil or criminal trial. 
(b)  The City Police Department shall furnish upon demand of any party to a civil or criminal trial, or upon demand of any court, a certificate showing whether a specific accident report was made to the department, and if so made: 
(1)  The date, time and location of the accident; 
(2)  The names and addresses of the drivers; and 
(3)  The names and addresses of the owners of the vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
ARTICLE IV. - BICYCLES 

Sec. 20-401. - Traffic laws apply to bicycle riders. 
    Every person riding a bicycle upon a street shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by this chapter, except: 
(1)  As to those special provisions contained in this article; and 
(2)  As to those provisions of this chapter which by their nature can have no application. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 0-9394-48, § 8, adopted August 9, 1994, amended the Code by deleting § 20-401 and renumbering §§ 20-402-20-407 as §§ 20-401-20-406. Formerly, § 20-401 pertained to licensing requirements and procedures for bicycles and derived from Ord. No. 0-7273-67. 
Sec. 20-402. - Riding upon bicycles. 
(a)  No person shall ride upon a bicycle other than astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto, and with at least one (1) hand upon the handlebars. 
(b)  No person shall carry persons upon a bicycle in excess of the number for which the bicycle was designed and equipped. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8485-84; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-401. 
Sec. 20-403. - Riding on sidewalk. 
(a)  No person shall ride a bicycle or skateboard upon any sidewalk or sidewalk area where such riding is specifically prohibited by signs. 
(b)  Persons exempt from the provisions of subsection (a) of this section are police officers on bicycles in the normal course of police duties who are exercising due caution. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9192-10; Ord. No. 0-9394-48; Ord. No. 0-9798-20) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-401. 
Sec. 20-404. - Riding on streets. 
(a)  Any person operating a bicycle upon a roadway at less than normal speed of traffic at the time and place and under the conditions then existing shall ride as close as practicable to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway, except under any of the following situations: 
(1)  When overtaking and passing another bicycle or vehicle proceeding in the same direction. 
(2)  When preparing for a left turn at an intersection or into a private road or driveway. 
(3)  When reasonably necessary to avoid conditions including, but not limited to, fixed or moving objects, parked or moving vehicles, bicycles, pedestrians, animals or surface hazards. 
(b)  Any person operating a bicycle on a one-way highway with two (2) or more marked traffic lanes may ride as near the left-hand curb or edge of such roadway as practicable. 
(c)  Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two (2) abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. Persons riding two (2) abreast shall not impede the normal and reasonable use of traffic and, on a laned roadway, shall ride within a single lane. 
(d)  A person riding a bicycle across a roadway and within a crosswalk shall walk the bicycle as a pedestrian and have all the rights and duties applicable to a pedestrian under the same circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8485-84; Ord. No. 0-9394-48; Ord. No. 0-9798-44) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-401. 
Sec. 20-405. - Carrying articles. 
    No person shall carry any packages, bundles or articles upon a bicycle which prevents the rider from keeping at least one (1) hand upon the handlebars. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-401. 
Sec. 20-406. - Parking. 
    No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than in a standing position upon the roadway against the curb, or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle, or against a building, or adjacent to the curb, in such a manner so as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Note- See editor's note, § 20-401. 
Sec. 20-407. - Bicycle racing. 
(a)  Bicycle racing on the highways is prohibited by section 20-547, except as authorized in this section. 
(b)  Bicycle racing on a highway shall not be unlawful when a racing event has been approved by State or City authorities. Approval of bicycle highway racing events shall be granted only under conditions which assure reasonable safety for all race participants, spectators and other highway users, and which prevent unreasonable interference with traffic flow which would seriously inconvenience other highway users. 
(c)  By agreement with the approving authority, participants in an approved bicycle highway racing event may be exempted from compliance with any traffic laws otherwise applicable thereto, provided that traffic control is adequate to assure the safety of all highway users. 
(Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
ARTICLE V. - DRIVING AND OPERATING A VEHICLE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administrative fine, in lieu of court appearance, for moving violations, § 14-310. 

Sec. 20-501. - Driving: Generally. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, no driver shall operate a vehicle other than to: 
(1)  Exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway; 
(2)  Give warning by sounding the horn when necessary; and 
(3)  Exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or confused or incapacitated individual upon the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-502. - Driving: Careless/Failure to devote full time and attention. 
(a)  The operator of every vehicle, while driving upon the streets and highways of this City, shall devote full time and attention to such driving, and the failure to do so shall be a violation. 
(b)  No person shall operate a vehicle carelessly, without due caution and circumspection, or in a manner so as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Sec. 20-503. - Driving: Controlled access. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle onto or from any controlled access or limited access roadway other than at such entrances and exits as established by the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-504. - Driving: On curbs. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle so as to proceed over or across any concrete curb, except as necessary to pick up or deliver building materials, household effects, or persons from or to premises abutting on such street. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-505. - Driving: Crossing fire hoses. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle so as to cross over any unprotected fire hose laid to be used at any fire, except with the consent of the Fire Department officer in command. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-506. - Driving: Divided streets. 
(a)  No person shall operate a vehicle other than upon the right portion of the roadway of any street divided into two (2) roadways by an intervening space, physical barrier, or clearly indicated dividing section. 
(b)  No person shall operate a vehicle over, across, or within any dividing space, barrier, or section dividing a street into two (2) roadways, except at openings, crossovers or intersections established by the City Manager. 
(c)  No person shall operate a vehicle other than upon the right lane of the right roadway of a divided street when that vehicle is a slow moving vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-507. - Driving: Following fire apparatus. 
    Other than upon official business, no person shall operate a vehicle so as to follow closer than three hundred (300) feet of any fire apparatus responding to a fire alarm, or approach or park that vehicle within three hundred (300) feet of any fire or fire apparatus stopped in a response to a fire alarm. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-508. - Driving: Following too closely. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle so as to follow another vehicle more closely than is reasonable and prudent, having due regard for the speed of such vehicle, traffic and street conditions. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-509. - Driving: License of driver. 
(a)  No person shall operate any vehicle upon the streets of the City without that person being licensed in the manner now required by the laws of the State of Oklahoma, which are hereby incorporated into the Code of the City of Norman as if fully set out in this subsection. 
(b)  No person shall operate any motor vehicle upon the streets of the City in violation of any restriction applied to his driver's license, pursuant to the laws of the State of Oklahoma, which are hereby incorporated into the Code of the City of Norman as if fully set out in this subsection. 
(c)  No person shall operate any motor vehicle upon the streets of the City at a time when his privilege to do so is cancelled, denied, suspended, or revoked pursuant to the laws of the State of Oklahoma, which are hereby incorporated into the Code of the City of Norman as if fully set out in this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 0-7475-14; Ord. No. 0-7879-17; Ord. 0-9192-26) 
Cross reference- Taxicab, bus, and limousine drivers to be licensed by City and State, §§ 13.2001, 13-2002. 
Sec. 20-510. - Driving: Licensing of vehicle. 
    No person shall operate any vehicle upon the streets of the City without that vehicle being licensed in the manner now provided by the law of the State of Oklahoma, which is hereby incorporated into the Code of the City of Norman as if fully set out in this section. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-7475-14; Ord. No. 0-7778-63; Ord. No. 0-7879-16) 
Sec. 20-511. - Driving: Limitations on backing. 
    No person shall back his vehicle: 
(1)  Into any intersection; or 
(2)  Unless such movement can be made with reasonable safety to other traffic, private or public property, or parked vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-7374-72) 
Sec. 20-512. - Driving: Meeting vehicles. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle approaching another vehicle proceeding in the opposite direction other than to pass that other vehicle to the right, giving that other vehicle half or as much of the main-traveled portion of the street as is nearly practicable. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-513. - Driving: Motor vehicle prohibitions on certain locations. 
(a)  No person shall operate any motor vehicle upon, over, or across any city park, public school grounds, recreational areas, parkways, drainage facilities or any other public right-of-way other than the streets used for motor vehicular traffic, or municipally owned land, except where so signed. 
(b)  No person shall operate any minibike or similar device upon, over, or across any street or alley except where so signed. 
(c)  Nor shall any person operate any minibike, motorcycle, motor scooter, moped, or similar device upon any property finally platted and zoned R-1, R-2, RM-2, R-3, RM-4, RM-6 or R-O, or within one-half (1/2) mile of any such residentially zoned property except in the following situations: 
(1)  Operation on a roadway as defined in section 20-123 of the Code; and 
(2)  Operation in a parking lot or driveway so long as such operation involves only reasonable ingress, egress, parking or storage of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-7576-42; Ord. No. 0-8485-84) 
Sec. 20-514. - Driving: Obstructed view. 
(a)  No person shall operate any vehicle so constructed or closed as to prevent the driver from having a clear view ahead and at the sides of such vehicle. 
(b)  No person shall operate any motor vehicle with any sign, poster, or other non-transparent material upon the front wind- shield, sidewings, or side or rear windows which prevents the driver from having a clear view of the highway or any intersecting highways. 
(c)  No person shall operate a vehicle so constructed or loaded as to obstruct the driver's view to the rear thereof, unless such vehicle is equipped with a mirror so as to reflect a view of the highway for a distance of at least two hundred (200) feet to the rear. 
(d)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle upon City streets in violation of state law concerning restrictions on use of glass coating materials or sun screening devices on windshields and windows as required by 47 Oklahoma Statutes, Section 12-422, which is hereby incorporated into the Code of the City with the same force and effect as if fully set out in this subsection. 
(e)  On application from a person required by medical reasons to be shielded from direct rays of the sun, supported by written affidavit of that fact from a licensed physician, the Department of Public Safety may issue an exemption from the requirements of this section for a motor vehicle belonging to the person or in which the person is a habitual passenger. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67 Ord. No. 0-8990-33; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Sec. 20-515. - Driving: One-way streets. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle upon any one-way street other than in the indicated direction, so long as signs indicating the direction of traffic flow are erected and maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-516. - Driving: Persons attached or clinging. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle whereupon a person using a bicycle, coaster, roller skates, skis, sled, or other device, has attached himself, or otherwise clings to that vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-517. - Driving: Processions or funerals. 
(a)  No person shall operate a vehicle so as to drive between the vehicles comprising an authorized procession or funeral while such vehicles are in motion and conspicuously designated as required by subsection (b). 
(b)  No person operating a vehicle in a procession or funeral shall operate that vehicle other than: 
(1)  Driving as nearly to the right-hand edge of the roadway as practicable; 
(2)  Following the other vehicle as closely as practicable; and 
(3)  Displaying full headlights. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Sec. 20-518. - Driving: Prohibited vehicles; prohibited loads; littering from vehicles; roadway obstructions; and damage to roadway. 
(a)  No person shall operate or move any vehicle or object which damages or is likely to damage the surface of a street. 
(b)  No person shall operate any vehicle so constructed or loaded, or in such condition as to cause delay in traffic, or constitute a hazard to person or property, except by permit issued by the Police Department. 
(c)  No person shall operate or convey through any street any vehicle which exceeds the width, height, length, weight, or load authorized by state law, except by permit issued by the Police Department or a state authority. 
(d)  No driver, operator, passenger or person of a vehicle shall throw or abandon litter upon public or private property. 
(e)  No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any roadway, unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any of its load from dropping, shifting, leaking, blowing or otherwise escaping therefrom, except that sand may be dropped for the purpose of securing traction, or water or other substances may be sprinkled on a roadway in cleaning or maintaining such roadway. 
(f)  No person shall operate on any roadway any vehicle with any load, unless said load and any covering thereon is securely fastened so as to prevent said covering or load from becoming loose, detached, or in any manner a hazard to other users of the roadway. Any vehicle loaded with sand, cinders, or other loose material susceptible to blowing or escaping by reason of wind shall have such load covered or dampened so as to prevent the blowing or escaping of said load from the vehicle. 
(g)  No person shall operate, or cause to be operated, a vehicle, any part of which is covered or laden with dirt, mud, clay or other material from any construction, excavation, parking or other site in such a manner or condition that the material will become tracked or shall fall upon the roadway, provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to persons who must enter upon improved or paved roadways from unimproved or nonpaved roadways or residential driveways. 
(h)  All vehicles used in the collection, removal and transportation of garbage, refuse, rubbish, or waste of any kind, shall, except when being loaded or unloaded, be kept completely and securely covered or otherwise enclosed so that no part of the contents thereof shall at any time be exposed to view. All such vehicles shall not be loaded above a point that will not permit its being drawn or driven over the streets or alleys without any portion of those contents being spilled or falling therefrom. Nor shall such vehicles be so loaded that their contents leak, spill, fall, or blow out of the vehicle into any public street, alley, public or private place while being drawn or driven through the City. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48; Ord. No. 0-9900-11; Ord. No. 0-0203-55; Ord. No. 0-0304-11; Ord. No. 0-0405-25, § 8) 
Sec. 20-519. - Driving: Reckless. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle in a willful and wanton manner without regard for the safety of any person or property, or in violation of the provisions of article X of this chapter. 
(Ord. No 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Sec. 20-520. - Driving: Right side on two-way streets. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle upon the left half of a two-way street of sufficient width, except when either passing another vehicle or when the right half is obstructed. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-521. - Driving: Right-of-way at intersection. 
(a)  No person shall operate a vehicle approaching an intersection other than to yield the right-of-way to any other vehicle which has entered that intersection from a different street or highway. 
(b)  No person shall operate a vehicle entering the same intersection at approximately the same time other than yielding the right-of-way to any vehicle on the right of that person. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-522. - Driving: On sidewalks. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle within or upon any sidewalk areas, except when such is part of a permanent or temporary driveway. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-523. - Driving: Starting parked vehicles. 
    No person shall start a vehicle which is stopped, standing, or parked unless and until such movement can be made with reasonable safety. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-524. - Driving: Stop when traffic obstructed. 
    Notwithstanding any traffic control signal indication to proceed, no person shall operate a vehicle so as to enter an intersection or marked crosswalk, unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate their vehicle without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-525. - Driving: Unauthorized person operating a vehicle. 
    No person shall cause, authorize, or knowingly permit any vehicle owned by him or under his control, to be driven upon any street, alley, or public place in the City by any persons not authorized under state law to so operate that vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-526. - Driving: Under the influence of an intoxicant. 
    The provisions of this section as provided in Title 47, § 761 (Operation of motor vehicle while impaired-Penalties-Suspensions-Violation not bondable), 11-902 (Persons under the influence of alcohol or other intoxicating substance or combination thereof-Penalty-Enhancement), and 11-906.4 (Operating or being in actual physical control of motor vehicle while under the influence while under age) of the Oklahoma Statutes, and any subsequent amendments thereto, are hereby incorporated into the Code the of the City with the same force and effect as if fully set out in this section. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-0708-9, § 1) 
Cross reference- Driver of taxicab, bus or limousine not to drink alcoholic beverages while on duty, § 13-2002. 
Sec. 20-527. - Driving: Transportation of alcoholic beverages. 
    No person shall transport in any vehicle upon any public street or alley any alcoholic beverage unless such is: 
(1)  In an unopened original container with seal unbroken and the original cap or cork not removed from the container; or 
(2)  The container is in the trunk or other closed compartment out of public view and inaccessible to the driver or any other occupant while the vehicle is in motion or while the driver is in actual physical control. 
(Ord. No. 0-9394-48; Ord. No. 0-9697-26; Ord. No. 0-1819-8, § 11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-9394-48, § 12, adopted Aug. 9, 1994, amended § 20-527 to read as set forth herein. Prior to such amendment, § 20-527 pertained to driving vehicles in procession and derived from Ord. No. 0-7273-67. Similar provisions are set out in § 20-517(b). 
Sec. 20-528. - Driving: Emergency vehicle approaching or passing a stationary emergency vehicle. 
(a)  Upon the approach of an emergency vehicle using those audible and visual signals required by section 20-112 of this Code, no person shall operate a vehicle other than to: 
(1)  Yield the right-of-way to such emergency vehicle; 
(2)  Drive to a position parallel to, and as close as possible to the right-hand edge or curb of the roadway, clear of any intersection; and 
(3)  Stop and remain stopped until that emergency vehicle has passed. 
(b)  The operator of a motor vehicle, when passing a stationary emergency vehicle, shall: 
(1)  Change lanes, if possible, into a lane that is not adjacent to the stationary emergency vehicle if traveling on a highway that consists of two or more lanes that carry traffic in the same direction of travel as that of the driver; or the driver shall reduce the speed of the motor vehicle if the driver is unable to change lanes or if doing so would be unsafe; or 
(2)  Reduce the speed of the motor vehicle if traveling on a highway other than described in subsection (b)(1); and 
(3)  Reduce speed and/or change lanes with due caution, at a speed and in a manner that is safe for existing road, traffic and weather conditions. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. O-0809-37, § 1) 
Sec. 20-529. - Passing: In no passing zone. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle so as to pass another vehicle in any designated no-passing zone, indicated either by yellow or other warning stripes within that person's lane of traffic, or by signs designating a no-passing zone except when lane is obstructed. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Sec. 20-530. - Passing: In school zone. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle so as to overtake and pass another vehicle within any school zone or school crossing zone in the City, except where there are two (2) or more marked lanes of travel in the same direction on each side of the centerline of the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8485-84) 
Sec. 20-531. - Passing: School bus. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle so as to proceed past any school bus which is stopped and which has the red loading signals thereupon activated, until such time that those loading signals have been deactivated; and only then may that person proceed past that school bus exercising due caution. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Sec. 20-532. - Passing: To the left. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle so as to overtake and pass, or attempt to overtake and pass, to the left of another vehicle, unless: 
(1)  The person overtaking shall pass at a safe distance to the left of the overtaken vehicle; and 
(2)  The overtaken vehicle gives way to the right upon audible signal in favor of the person overtaking, and said vehicle does not increase its speed until completely passed by the person overtaking; and 
(3)  The person overtaking does not drive to the left of the centerline of the street during this movement until that side is clearly visible and free of oncoming traffic for a sufficient distance ahead to permit that movement to be made in safety; and 
(4)  No part of the overtaking and passing is within one hundred (100) feet of any railroad crossing, street intersection or bridge. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-533. - Passing: To the right. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle so as to overtake and pass, or attempt to overtake and pass, to the right of another vehicle, unless: 
(1)  The movement can be safely made without driving off the pavement or the main travelled portion of the roadway; and 
(2)  The overtaken vehicle is making or about to make a left turn, or is in the left portion of the roadway having sufficient width for two (2) or more lines of moving vehicles in the same direction; and 
(3)  The street beyond the overtaken vehicle is unobstructed. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8485-84) 
Sec. 20-534. - Turning: Left on two-way roadway. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle so as to approach and execute a left turn at an intersection where traffic moves in both directions on each roadway entering that intersection other than by: 
(1)  Approaching that intersection in the right half of the roadway nearest the centerline thereof; and 
(2)  Passing to the right of such centerline where it enters that intersection; and 
(3)  After entering that intersection, making the left turn so as to leave that intersection to the right of the centerline of the roadway being entered, in or as close as possible to the lane closest to the centerline; and 
(4)  When practicable, making that turn in the portion of that intersection to the left of the center of that intersection. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8485-84) 
Sec. 20-535. - Turning: Left on other than two-way roadway. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle so as to approach and execute a left turn at any intersection where traffic is restricted to one direction on one (1) or more of the roadways other than by: 
(1)  Approaching that intersection in the extreme left-hand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in the same direction as the person is travelling; and 
(2)  After entering that intersection, making the left turn so as to leave the intersection as nearly as practicable in the left-hand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in that direction upon the roadway being entered. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-3182-24) 
Sec. 20-536. - Turning: Right. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle so as to approach and execute a right turn other than by: 
(1)  Moving as close as practicable to the right hand curb or edge of the roadway, and 
(2)  After entering that intersection, making the right turn so as to leave that intersection as nearly as practicable in the right hand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in that direction upon the roadway being entered. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-537. - Turning: Right-of-way for left turns. 
    The driver of a vehicle intending to turn to the left within an intersection or into an alley, private road or driveway shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle approaching from the opposite direction which is within the intersection or so close thereto as to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8081-34) 
Sec. 20-538. - Turning or changing lanes: Other than intersections. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle so as to change lanes, turn from a direct course, or move to the right or left of a roadway, unless and until such movement can be made with reasonable safety. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8485-84) 
Sec. 20-539. - Turning: Through service drive. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle so as to turn into and drive through any service drive located at a street intersection without stopping within such service drive for the purpose of obtaining service or merchandise. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8485-84) 
Sec. 20-540. - Turning: Use of signals. 
(a)  No person shall turn a vehicle to the right or left except upon their continuously giving a signal of intention during not less than the last one hundred (100) feet travelled by the vehicle before the turning movement. 
(b)  The signal of an intention to turn may be given by means of either a signal lamp or by the hand and arm of the driver, in which case such hand and arm signal shall be in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-541. - Turning: U-turns. 
(a)  Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall operate a vehicle so as to turn more than ninety (90) degrees on any street or highway. 
(b)  Persons excepted are those who can safely execute that turn: 
(1)  At an intersection not controlled by traffic control devices, so long as that turn does not interfere with other traffic. 
(2)  At a signalized intersection controlled by a traffic signal where there is a sign posted that specifically allows the U-turn maneuver. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-1213-43, § 1) 
Sec. 20-542. - Fleeing or attempting to elude a police officer. 
    Any driver of a motor vehicle who willfully fails or refuses to bring his vehicle to a stop, or who otherwise flees or attempts to elude a pursuing police vehicle, when given visual or audible signal to bring the vehicle to a stop, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. The signal given by the police officer may be by hand, voice, emergency light or siren. The officer giving such signal shall be in uniform, prominently displaying his badge of office and his vehicle shall be appropriately marked showing it to be an official police vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 0-8081-33) 
Sec. 20-543. - Carrying of security verification form while operating vehicle. 
    Every operator of a motor vehicle registered in this state, shall, while operating or using such vehicle, carry either an operator's or an owner's current Security Verification Form issued by an insurance carrier, providing the operator is not excluded from coverage thereon; or an equivalent form issued by the Oklahoma Department of Public Safety, reflecting the liability coverage. The Security Verification Form or its equivalent shall contain the information required by Article VI, Chapter 7 of Title 47 of the Oklahoma Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 0-8384-13) 
Sec. 20-544. - Overtaking bicycles. 
    When overtaking and passing a bicycle proceeding in the same direction, a person driving a motor vehicle shall exercise due care by leaving a safe distance between the motor vehicle and the bicycle of not less than three (3) feet until the motor vehicle is safely past the overtaken bicycle. 
(Ord. No. 0-1011-12, § 1) 
Sec. 20-545. - Transportation of children by day care centers. 
    Day care centers that provide transportation for children to or from the center must comply with the following: 
1.  Adult/child ratio. When transporting children, the following guide for appropriate adult/child ratios shall be used. 
(a)  For children under four (4) years of age, the driver shall not be counted in attaining the appropriate ratio. 
(1)  Toddlers (approximately age ten (10) months to two (2) years), at least one adult to six (6) children. 
(2)  Two (2) years and up to but not including age three (3), at least one adult to eight (8) children. 
(3)  Three (3) years and up to but not including age four (4), at least one adult to twelve (12) children. 
(b)  For children four (4) years of age and older, the driver may be counted toward meeting the adult/child ratios. 
(1)  Four (4) years up to but not including age six (6), at least one adult to fifteen (15) children. 
(2)  Six (6) years and over, at least one adult to twenty (20) children. 
(3)  Mixed ages: When children of two (2) or more ages are grouped together, ages shall be averaged to determine the proper adult/child ratio provided there shall be at least one adult, excluding the driver, to eight (8) children and no more than two (2) of these eight (8) children shall be under two (2) years of age or children that require special attention. 
2.  Seating requirements. 
(a)  All children to be transported must be seated at all times when the vehicle is moving. Adults must not allow children to stand in the vehicle while it is moving, or allow any part of a child's body to extend from the windows. 
(b)  To be transported, all children over the age of two (2) must each individually use a separate, properly secured seat belt or child passenger restraint system. 
(c)  To be transported, all children age two (2) or under must each individually use a separate, properly secured safety seat or child passenger restraint system. 
3.  Vehicles. 
(a)  All vehicles used to transport children must have operable door locks. The driver shall be responsible for keeping the doors locked at all times while the vehicle is moving. 
(b)  Vehicles containing children shall never be left unattended. 
(c)  Vehicles used by a day care center to transport children must be marked with the name and address of the facility so that children and others can identify it. 
4.  Definitions and general provisions. 
(a)  Day care center: Unless specifically exempted within this chapter, "day care center" shall include child care establishments as defined in section 13-501 of the Norman Code, preschools, Mother's Day Out programs, and other such child care operations carried on in places other than the residence of the children to whom the care is being given. 
(b)  Child passenger restraint system: Shall mean infant or child passenger restraint system that meets the Federal Standards for crash tested restraint systems as set by the United States Department of Transportation. 
(c)  Vehicles: Shall mean every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is, or may be, transported or drawn, including buses, vans and cars. 
(d)  This section 20-545 shall apply to any person transporting children and acting pursuant to permission or authorization of a day care center whether such person is an employee of or a volunteer for the day care center. 
5.  Loading and unloading. 
    There must be provided safe conduct to and from all cars, and safe off-street loading space, so that the children are protected from backing cars, from being between cars, and from all traffic hazards. 
6.  Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  Police officers shall be empowered to stop day care center vehicles for the purpose of determining compliance with the above subsection. The staff/child ratio may also be enforced when the day care center vehicle is stopped at its destination, during loading or unloading. 
(b)  Citations for the violations enumerated above shall be given to the driver or operator of the day care center vehicle involved. The fine shall not be less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(c)  The second and subsequent violations of any of the above subsections shall be reported to the Day Care Licensing Department of the Oklahoma Department of Human Services. 
(Ord. No. 0-8485-84; Ord. No. 0-9900-11) 
Cross reference- Child care establishments, § 13-501 et seq. 
Sec. 20-546. - Driving: Passengers on motorcycles, mopeds, minibikes or motor scooters. 
    No driver of a motorcycle, moped, minibike or motor scooter shall carry any other person upon or on that vehicle unless that vehicle complies with the requirements of section 20-603(6), and the driver of that vehicle is more than sixteen (16) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 0-8485-84) 
Sec. 20-547. - Racing on highways. 
(a)  No person shall drive [on a highway] any vehicle in any race, speed competition or contest, drag race or acceleration contest, test of physical endurance, exhibition of speed or acceleration, or for the purpose of making a speed record, and no person in any manner [shall] participate in any such race, competition, contest, test or exhibition. 
(b)  "Drag race" is defined as the operation of two (2) or more vehicles from a point side by side at accelerating speeds in a competitive attempt to outdistance each other, or the operation of one (1) or more vehicles over a common selected course, from the same point to the same point or power of acceleration of such vehicle or vehicles within a certain distance of time limit. 
(c)  "Racing" is defined as the use of one (1) or more vehicles in an attempt to outgain, outdistance, or prevent another vehicle from passing, to arrive at a given destination ahead of another vehicle or vehicles, or to test the physical stamina or endurance of drivers over long distance driving routes. 
(Ord. No. 0-9394-48) 
Sec. 20-548. - Transporting a firearm improperly. 
    Any person stopped pursuant to a moving traffic violation who is transporting a loaded pistol in the motor vehicle without a valid concealed handgun permit authorized by the Oklahoma Self-Defense Act or valid license from another state, whether the loaded firearm is concealed or open in the vehicle is deemed to be transporting a firearm improperly. Title 21 of the Oklahoma State Statues pertaining to firearms are hereby incorporated herein. 
(Ord. No. 0-0304-11) 
ARTICLE VI. - EQUIPMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administrative fine, in lieu of court appearance, for equipment violations, § 14-310(d)(1); prohibition against removal or disconnection of required motor vehicle pollution devices, § 10-106. 

Sec. 20-601. - Authority to inspect. 
    The Police Department has the authority to inspect and test any vehicle upon the streets of the City at any time to determine whether it is properly equipped as required by state law or this Code, and whether such equipment is properly functioning. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-602. - Required equipment. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, no person shall operate a vehicle upon the streets of the City unless it is equipped with: 
(1)  Brakes, 
(2)  Flags, 
(3)  Horns or other warning devices, 
(4)  Lights, 
(5)  Mirrors and safety glass, 
(6)  Mufflers suitable, sufficient and in constant operation so as to prevent excessive noise, and 
(7)  Tires, 
as required by Title 47, Oklahoma Statutes, section 12-201 et seq., 12-301 et seq., 12-401 et seq., which are hereby incorporated into the Code of the City of Norman, Oklahoma with the same force and effect as if fully set out in this subsection. 
(b)  All such required equipment shall be used when and as required by said applicable state law. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-7475-14) 
Sec. 20-603. - Additional equipment requirements for motorcycles and motor scooters. 
(a)  No person shall operate a motorcycle, motor scooter or moped on the streets of the City unless it is equipped with: 
(1)  Brakes adequate to control the movement; including two (2) separate means of applying the brakes, one for the front wheel and one for the rear; 
(2)  Fenders over each wheel, as provided by the manufacturer; 
(3)  Handlebars not exceeding twelve (12) inches in height, as measured from the point of attachment; 
(4)  One lighted headlamp capable of showing a white light visible at least three hundred (300) feet forward; 
(5)  Two (2) rear view mirrors, containing a reflecting surface of not less than three (3) inches in diameter, mounted one on each side of the vehicle and so positioned as to enable the driver to clearly view not less than two hundred (200) feet to the rear; 
(6)  A double seating device and double foot rests (or a side car attachment) should the wheel diameter equal or exceed twelve (12) inches; 
(7)  A speedometer capable of registering at least thirty-five (35) m.p.h.; 
(8)  A taillight, mounted on the rear, which when lighted emits a red light visible at least three hundred (300) feet to the rear; 
(9)  A windshield of sufficient quality, size and thickness to protect the driver from foreign objects, though in lieu thereof, the operator may wear goggles or face shield of sufficient material and design to protect him from foreign objects. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, no person shall operate a motorcycle, motor scooter or moped on the streets of the City at any time, without the headlamp being on. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8485-84) 
Sec. 20-604. - Crash helmets required. 
    No person under eighteen (18) years of age shall operate or otherwise ride on a motorcycle, motor scooter or moped on the streets of the City without wearing on his head a crash helmet of the type and design manufactured for such use, and consisting of lining, padding, and chin strap. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-7677-2; Ord. No. 0-8485-84) 
Sec. 20-605. - Bicycle and other conveyance equipment. 
(a)  No person shall operate a bicycle on the streets of the City unless it is equipped with: 
(1)  A brake which will enable the operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement; 
(2)  A light (when such bicycle is used between one-half hour before sunset and one-half hour after sunrise), which shall emit a white light visible at least five hundred (500) feet forward; 
(3)  A red reflector (when such bicycle is used between one-half hour before sunset and one-half hour after sunrise) on the rear of the bicycle, which shall be visible from all distances from fifty (50) feet to three hundred (300) feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful upper beams of head amps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. 
(4)  Bicycle safety helmets are required for children under the age of eighteen (18) years of age. Helmets shall have been approved by Snell or ANSI. 
(5)  Seat belts and safety helmets (Snell- or ANSI-approved) are required for children under the age of six (6) years of age riding in bicycle carriers and trailers. 
(b)  No person shall operate any animal-drawn vehicle upon the streets of the City during nighttime without displaying thereupon a lighted lamp visible at least five hundred (500) feet to the rear. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-9798-44; Ord. No. 0-0304-31, § 1) 
Sec. 20-606. - Prohibited equipment. 
    No person shall operate any vehicle equipped with: 
(1)  Mufflers or an exhaust system 
[a]  Equipped with a cut-out, by-pass, exhaust, whistle, or other similar device, or 
[b]  So altered to amplify or increase noise levels above those permitted by the muffler originally installed on the vehicle; 
(2)  A red light or red glass or reflector mounted on the front, top, or sides, unless it be an emergency vehicle; 
(3)  Any other equipment prohibited by state law. 
(Ord. No. § 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-607. - Child passenger restraint system. 
(a)  Every driver, when transporting a child under eight (8) years of age in a motor vehicle operated on the roadways, streets, or highways of this state, shall provide for the protection of said child by properly using a child passenger restraint system as follows: 
(1)  A child under four (4) years of age shall be properly secured in a child passenger restraint system. The child passenger restraint system shall be rear-facing until the child reaches two (2) years of age or until the child reaches the weight or height limit of the rear-facing child passenger restraint system as allowed by the manufacturer of the child passenger restraint system, whichever occurs first; and 
(2)  A child at least four (4) years of age but younger than eight (8) years of age, if not taller than four (4) feet nine (9) inches in height, shall be properly secured in either a child passenger restraint system or child booster seat. 
    For purposes of this section, "child passenger restraint system" means an infant or child passenger restraint system which meets the Federal Standards as set by 49 C.F.R., Section 571.213. 
(b)  If a child is eight (8) years of age or is taller than four (4) feet nine (9) inches in height, a seat belt properly secured to the vehicle shall be sufficient to meet the requirements of this section. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  The driver of a school bus, taxicab, moped, motorcycle, or other motor vehicle not required to be equipped with safety belts pursuant to state or federal laws; 
(2)  The driver of an ambulance or emergency vehicle; 
(3)  The driver of a vehicle in which all of the seat belts are in use; 
(4)  The transportation of children who for medical reasons are unable to be placed in such devices, provided there is written documentation from a physician of such medical reason; or 
(5)  The transportation of a child who weighs more than forty (40) pounds and who is being transported in the back seat of a vehicle while wearing only a lap safety belt when the back seat of the vehicle is not equipped with combination lap and shoulder safety belts, or when the combination lap and shoulder safety belts in the back seat are being used by other children who weigh more than forty (40) pounds. Provided, however, for purposes of this paragraph, back seat shall include all seats located behind the front seat of a vehicle operated by a licensed child care facility or church. Provided further, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that a child has met the weight requirements of this paragraph if at the request of any law enforcement officer, the licensed child care facility or church provides the officer with a written statement verified by the parent or legal guardian that the child weighs more than forty (40) pounds. 
(d)  A violation of the provisions of this section shall be admissible as evidence in any civil action or proceeding for damages unless the plaintiff in such action or proceeding is a child under sixteen (16) years of age. 
    In any action brought by or on behalf of an infant for personal injuries or wrongful death sustained in a motor vehicle collision, the failure of any person to have the infant properly restrained in accordance with the provisions of this section shall not be used in aggravation or mitigation of damages. 
(e)  A person who is certified as a Child Passenger Safety Technician and who in good faith provides inspection, adjustment, or educational services regarding child passenger restraint systems shall not be liable for civil damages resulting from any act or omission in providing such services, other than acts or omissions constituting gross negligence or willful or wanton misconduct. 
(f)  Any person convicted of violating subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall be punished by a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) and shall pay all court costs thereof. 
(g)  This section shall become effective on November 1, 2015. 
(Ord. No. 0-8788-15; Ord. No. 0-9596-1; Ord. No. 0-1011-36, § 1; Ord. No. 0-1516-14, § 4) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 0-1011-36, adopted Jan. 11, 2011, changed the title of § 20-607 from "Motor vehicle equipment for children under the age of six" to "Child passenger restraint system." 
Sec. 20-608. - Mandatory use of seatbelts. 
    The provisions for the mandatory use of seatbelts as provided in Title 47, Section 12-417, Oklahoma Statutes, and any subsequent amendments thereto, are hereby incorporated into the Code of the City with the same force and effect as if fully set out in this section. 
(Ord. No. 0-9091-4) 
Sec. 20-609. - Unlawful operation of a motor vehicle while texting. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle on any street or highway within this state while using a hand-held electronic communication device to manually compose, send or read an electronic text message while the motor vehicle is in motion. 
(b)  Any person who violates the provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(c)  The provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply if the person is using the cellular telephone or electronic communication device for the sole purpose of communicating with any of the following regarding an imminent emergency situation: 
(1)  An emergency response operator; 
(2)  A hospital, physician's office or health clinic; 
(3)  A provider of ambulance services; 
(4)  A provider of firefighting services; or 
(5)  A law enforcement agency. 
(d)  For the purpose of this section: 
(1)  Cellular telephone means an analog or digital wireless telephone authorized by the Federal Communications Commission to operate in the frequency bandwidth reserved for cellular telephones; 
(2)  Compose , send or read with respect to a text message means the manual entry, sending or retrieval of a text message to communicate with any person or device; 
(3)  Electronic communication device means an electronic device that permits the user to manually transmit a communication of written text by means other than through an oral transfer or wire communication. This term does not include a device that is physically or electronically integrated into a motor vehicle or a voice-operated global positioning or navigation system that is affixed to a motor vehicle, or a hands-free device that allows the user to write, send or read a text message without the use of either hand except to activate, deactivate or initiate a feature or function; and 
(4)  Text message includes a text-based message, instant message, electronic message, photo, video or electronic mail. 
(Ord. No. 0-1516-13, § 4) 
Editor's note- Section 5 of Ord. No. 0-1516-13, adopted Sept. 22, 2015, states "this section shall become effective on November 1, 2015." 
ARTICLE VII. - IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Sale of impounded vehicles, § 8-304 et seq. 

Sec. 20-701. - Authority to impound. 
(a)  The City Police Department is authorized to remove and impound any vehicle to a public or private storage yard when: 
(1)  The vehicle is left unattended upon a bridge, viaduct, causeway, tube or tunnel, and it constitutes a hazard or obstruction to traffic; 
(2)  The vehicle is left unattended upon any street, and the person in charge of that vehicle is incapacitated by physical injury to provide for its custody or removal, and it constitutes a hazard or obstruction to traffic; 
(3)  The vehicle is left unattended upon any street, is illegally parked, and it constitutes a hazard or obstruction to traffic; 
(4)  The vehicle has been involved in one or more moving violations of this chapter, and the driver did not respond to those issued citations; 
(5)  The vehicle is used upon the streets with defective or inoperable brakes, or is used at night when both headlights are defective or inoperable; 
(6)  Any vehicle found where a report or complaint has previously been made alleging that the vehicle has been stolen; 
(7)  When an officer arrests any person driving or in control of a vehicle for an alleged offense and the officer is by ordinance or state statute required or permitted to take and does take the person arrested before a duly appointed judge; 
(8)  An officer arrests any person driving or in control of a vehicle who does not have in their possession a valid Oklahoma driver's license or a valid driver's license issued by another state; 
(9)  The vehicle is parked in a marked handicapped parking space and the vehicle displays no handicapped parking decal; 
(10)  The vehicle is parked in any parking area marked by sign or otherwise as a "Tow-Away" zone; 
(11)  The vehicle is left unattended on public property, and is parked illegally or where such parking is prohibited by sign or other marking; 
(12)  The vehicle is left unattended and parked on public property and has three (3) or more parking violations of this chapter which remain unpaid and delinquent on the date of impoundment. 
(b)  Subsequent to a written complaint signed by the owner, occupant, or person in charge of private property, or the investigating police officer, the City Police Department is authorized to remove and impound any vehicle to a public or private storage yard when: 
(1)  The vehicle is parked on private property without the consent first had and obtained of the owner, occupant, or person in charge of that private property; 
(2)  The vehicle is found parked in front of, or blocking any private driveway or public alley; 
(3)  The vehicle is parked between the curb, curbline, or roadway edge of a public street and a private property line or sidewalk; 
(4)  The vehicle is illegally parked for a period in excess of twenty-four (24) hours; 
(5)  The vehicle is left unattended and is parked illegally or without proper authorization upon public property. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-7475-37; Ord. No. 0-7980-18; Ord. No. 0-8485-84; Ord. No. 0-0506-10; Ord. No. 0-0708-9, § 2) 
Sec. 20-702. - Police Department to attempt to ascertain owner. 
    Upon the removal and impoundment of any vehicle, the City Police Department shall attempt to ascertain the name and address of the owner from the registration records of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-703. - Notice of impoundment to be given. 
(a)  If the owner of an impounded vehicle is ascertained, the City Police Department shall immediately give or cause to give a written notice of the removal and impoundment to the owner. 
(b)  If the owner of an impounded vehicle is not ascertained, or the City Police Department is otherwise unable to give notice to said owner, and the vehicle is not redeemed within three (3) days, the City Police Department shall send or cause to be sent a written report of removal and impoundment to the Oklahoma State Department whose duty it is to register motor vehicles. 
(c)  Any notice given shall include a complete description of the vehicle, the date, time and place of removal, the reasons for removal, and the name of the garage or place where the vehicle is stored. 
(d)  The City Police Department shall provide a copy of any notice given to the proprietor of the garage or place where the vehicle is stored. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-704. - Redemption of impounded vehicles. 
    Any impounded vehicle pursuant to this article shall be delivered to the owner or agent thereof, only subsequent to the posting of any required bond, the payment of any fines and costs assessed by the Court for violations of this chapter, and the towage and storage charges. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Cross reference- Administrative costs for impoundment of vehicles, §§ 14-310(f), 14-311(d). 
Sec. 20-705. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-0708-9, § 3, adopted Oct. 9, 2007, deleted § 20-705 in its entirety. Former § 20-705 pertained to towing and storage charges and derived from Ord. No. 0-7273-67. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PARKING, STOPPING, AND STANDING[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Prohibition against parking of vehicles loaded with liquefied petroleum gas, § 9-206(b). 

Sec. 20-801. - Parking or standing near curbs; brake and motor requirements. 
    No person shall park or stand a vehicle upon a roadway where there are adjacent curbs without: 
(1)  Adequate brakes being set; 
(2)  The motor of the vehicle left not running; and 
(3)  The right-hand wheels of that vehicle being within eighteen (18) inches of curb or edge of the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-7778-24) 
Sec. 20-802. - Parking in accordance with signs or markings. 
    No person shall park or leave any vehicle in a parking meter zone other than: 
(1)  At the approximate angle indicated by the lines marking those particular parking spaces, and 
(2)  Within the space marked by such lines. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-803. - Parking meter usage. 
(a)  A person shall only use a metered space according to the directions on the parking meter and posted City signs, including the insertion of necessary payment in the parking meter for any desired period of time. Parking meter rates and times shall be established administratively by the City Manager or his designee. 
(b)  No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meters any method of payment, including coins other than those of the United States, other than those approved methods of payment as indicated by the directions on the meters. 
(c)  No person shall increase or extend the parking time of any vehicle using a metered space beyond the legal parking time established for that space as indicated on the face of that meter. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-0405-40, § 1; Ord. No. 0-1314-6, § 1) 
Sec. 20-804. - Parking presumption. 
(a)  It shall be presumed that the registered owner of any vehicle found parked in violation of this chapter was that person who parked or placed such vehicle in violation thereof whenever the City presents evidence that the particular vehicle described in the citation was parked in violation of this chapter and that the defendant named therein was, at the time of such violation, the registered owner of that vehicle. 
(b)  The effect of the above presumption is to shift the burden of proof to the named defendant. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67) 
Sec. 20-805. - Parking, stopping, or standing not to obstruct traffic. 
    No person shall park, stop, or stand a vehicle: 
(1)  Upon a bridge, or other elevated structure; 
(2)  On a crosswalk; 
(3)  In front of a public or another person's private drive; 
(4)  Within an intersection; 
(5)  Within any bicycle lane; 
(6)  On any railroad tracks; 
(7)  Facing the opposite way from the normal flow of traffic; 
(8)  On the left side of any one-way street, unless otherwise so signed; 
(9)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction; 
(10)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb; 
(11)  In an alley in such manner as to leave less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway available for the free movement of traffic; 
(12)  On a sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-7475-61) 
Sec. 20-806. - Parking, stopping, and standing prohibited within certain distances. 
    No person shall park, stop, or stand a vehicle: 
(1)  Within ten (10) feet of an alley intersection; 
(2)  Within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant; 
(3)  Within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk; 
(4)  Within thirty (30) feet of any flashing signal, stop sign, or traffic control signal; 
(5)  Within thirty (30) feet of any fire station driveway, or when so signed, within seventy-five (75) feet on the side of the street opposite the entrance to a fire station; 
(6)  Within thirty (30) feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone; 
(7)  Within fifty (50) feet of the nearest rail or railroad crossing; 
(8)  So as to double park within fifty (50) feet of a street intersection; 
(9)  Within fifty (50) feet of any intersection without crosswalks. 
(Ord. No. 0-7273-67; Ord. No. 0-8485-84) 
Sec. 20-807. - Parking, stopping and standing prohibited in other areas. 
    No person shall park, stop, or stand a vehicle: 
(1)  Where prohibited by sign; 
(2)  Upon a street or approved cutback: 
[a]  Unless otherwise allowed by signs, for a time period exceeding twenty-four (24) hours; 
[b]  To display that vehicle for sale; 
[c]  For washing, greasing, or repairs, except as necessitated by emergency; 
[d]  Adjacent to a yellow painted curb; 
(3)  On any private drive or property without the prior consent of the owner or that person legally in possession of such property; 
(4)  In that space between the curb, curbline, or roadway edge and the private property line along any street, unless parking is in an approved cutback provided for such parking; 
(5)  In a bus stop or taxicab stand, except: 
[a]  When the vehicle is respectively a bus or a taxicab; or 
[b]  That person is temporarily stopped therein for the purpose of and engaged in loading or unloading passengers, so long as that does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter the designated area; 
(6)  On the roadway side of any vehicle parked or stopped at the edge of a street curb, except for the expeditious loading or unloading of: 
[a]  Passengers, for a time period not to exceed three (3) minutes; or 
[b]  Freight, for a time period not to exceed ten (10) minutes; 
(7)  At any curb loading zone, except for the loading or unloading of passengers or freight; 
(8)  In a parking space designated and signed for handicapped drivers, whether on public or private property, unless the vehicle to be parked displays a handicapped parking permit issued by the State of Oklahoma, to the driver or a passenger present during use of the permit, or the state of residence of such a person; 
(9)  In any fire lanes, whether on public or private property; 
(10)  On any public property without proper authorization.
